LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We were at a particularly tipsy table. The air was thick with the mingled scents of gin and cigarette smoke, and the laughter that rose and fell around us was the kind that comes from too much liquor and too little restraint. It was one of those summer nights in West Egg that seemed to stretch on forever, the kind that made time feel irrelevant and the world feel like a dream. The party was in full swing, and the house was alive with the kind of energy that only the wealthy and the reckless could summon so effortlessly.

I had been invited, as I often was, to one of Gatsby’s grand soirées. The guests were a curious mix—some were old money, others were new money, and a few were simply people who had heard of Gatsby and wanted to see what the fuss was about. There was a certain kind of glamour to the event, a kind of glittering chaos that made it impossible to look away. Gatsby himself was a ghost in the crowd, appearing only when necessary, always in the background, always watching.

At our table, the conversation had taken a turn toward the absurd. Someone had just told a story about a man who had driven his Rolls-Royce into a lake and then swam out with the car door still in his hand. The story was met with a round of applause and a few more drinks. I sipped my gin and tonic slowly, trying to keep my wits about me, but even I was beginning to feel the pull of the night’s intoxicating rhythm.

Across from me sat Jordan Baker, her eyes sharp and her smile just a little too knowing. She was one of those people who could make a room feel like a stage, and she was clearly enjoying the performance. “You know,” she said, leaning in slightly, “Gatsby’s got a way of making people believe in things that don’t exist.”

I raised an eyebrow. “Like what?”

She took a sip of her drink and looked around the room as if Gatsby himself might appear at any moment. “Like the past,” she said. “Like the idea that you can go back and fix things. That you can rewrite history with enough money and enough charm.”

I didn’t know what to say to that. I had always been skeptical of Gatsby’s dream, but I had never been able to put it into words. Now, with Jordan’s words hanging in the air, I felt the weight of it settle in my chest.

The music changed, and a slow, sultry tune began to play. A few couples took to the dance floor, their movements graceful and deliberate. I watched them for a moment, thinking about how easy it was to lose yourself in the moment, to forget the world outside the house, to forget the things that couldn’t be changed.

Gatsby appeared at the edge of the room, his smile wide and his eyes searching. He looked like a man who had everything but was still waiting for something. I wondered, not for the first time, what it was he was waiting for. Was it Daisy? Was it the past? Or was it something even more elusive, something that could never be captured, no matter how much money or charm he had?

The night wore on, and the party continued. The guests came and went, the music played on, and the lights stayed bright. But beneath the surface of the revelry, there was a kind of sadness that I couldn’t shake. It was the kind of sadness that came from knowing that no matter how hard you tried, you couldn’t change the past. You couldn’t rewrite the story. You could only live in the present, and even that was fleeting.

As the night began to wind down, I found myself standing on the steps of the house, watching the last of the guests leave. The air was cool now, and the stars were beginning to show through the haze of the city. I thought about Gatsby, about his dream, about the way he had tried so hard to make it real. And I thought about the fact that in the end, no amount of money or charm could bring back the past. It was gone, and it was gone for good.

I turned and walked back into the house, the echoes of laughter and music still lingering in the air. The party was over, but the dream was still alive. And maybe, just maybe, that was enough.

events.title: Gatsby's Post-Party Despair and Obsession with Repeating the Past
detailed_summary: Nick waits for Gatsby after the party guests have left.
Gatsby finally appears, looking strained and tired.
He immediately tells Nick that Daisy disliked the party and didn't have a good time.
Nick senses Gatsby's profound depression and feelings of distance from Daisy.
Gatsby reveals his ultimate desire: for Daisy to tell Tom she never loved him.
He believes this declaration would erase the past four years, allowing them to return to Louisville and marry as if it were five years ago.
He expresses frustration that Daisy doesn't seem to understand or accept this plan.
Nick advises Gatsby not to demand too much from Daisy, stating, 'You can't repeat the past'.
Gatsby reacts with incredulous disagreement, passionately insisting that the past *can* be repeated.
He vows to 'fix everything just the way it was before'.
Gatsby talks extensively about the past, conveying his longing to recover something essential—perhaps an idealized version of himself—that became intertwined with loving Daisy.
He feels his life has been disordered since losing her and believes returning to a specific 'starting place' could clarify what was lost.
He recounts a specific memory: walking with Daisy on a moonlit autumn night five years earlier.
He describes the magical atmosphere and his perception of the sidewalk as a symbolic ladder to a higher realm attainable only alone.
He recalls the moment before kissing Daisy, realizing that doing so would forever bind his 'unutterable visions' to her 'perishable breath,' ending his purely imaginative, god-like state.
He paused, then kissed her, feeling her 'blossom' and completing the 'incarnation' of his dream.
Listening to Gatsby's intensely sentimental story, Nick feels a fleeting sense of recognition, as if recalling a lost fragment of wisdom or language.
However, the feeling remains elusive and ultimately 'uncommunicable'.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But they made no sound, and what I had almost remembered was uncommunicable forever.

events.text_segment:
I stayed late that night. Gatsby asked me to wait until he was free, and I lingered in the garden until the inevitable swimming party had run up, chilled and exalted, from the black beach, until the lights were extinguished in the guestrooms overhead. When he came down the steps at last the tanned skin was drawn unusually tight on his face, and his eyes were bright and tired.
“She didn’t like it,” he said immediately.
“Of course she did.”
“She didn’t like it,” he insisted. “She didn’t have a good time.”
He was silent, and I guessed at his unutterable depression.
“I feel far away from her,” he said. “It’s hard to make her understand.”
“You mean about the dance?”
“The dance?” He dismissed all the dances he had given with a snap of his fingers. “Old sport, the dance is unimportant.”
He wanted nothing less of Daisy than that she should go to Tom and say: “I never loved you.” After she had obliterated four years with that sentence they could decide upon the more practical measures to be taken. One of them was that, after she was free, they were to go back to Louisville and be married from her house—just as if it were five years ago.
“And she doesn’t understand,” he said. “She used to be able to understand. We’d sit for hours—”
He broke off and began to walk up and down a desolate path of fruit rinds and discarded favours and crushed flowers.
“I wouldn’t ask too much of her,” I ventured. “You can’t repeat the past.”
“Can’t repeat the past?” he cried incredulously. “Why of course you can!”
He looked around him wildly, as if the past were lurking here in the shadow of his house, just out of reach of his hand.
“I’m going to fix everything just the way it was before,” he said, nodding determinedly. “She’ll see.”
He talked a lot about the past, and I gathered that he wanted to recover something, some idea of himself perhaps, that had gone into loving Daisy. His life had been confused and disordered since then, but if he could once return to a certain starting place and go over it all slowly, he could find out what that thing was…
… One autumn night, five years before, they had been walking down the street when the leaves were falling, and they came to a place where there were no trees and the sidewalk was white with moonlight. They stopped here and turned toward each other. Now it was a cool night with that mysterious excitement in it which comes at the two changes of the year. The quiet lights in the houses were humming out into the darkness and there was a stir and bustle among the stars. Out of the corner of his eye Gatsby saw that the blocks of the sidewalks really formed a ladder and mounted to a secret place above the trees—he could climb to it, if he climbed alone, and once there he could suck on the pap of life, gulp down the incomparable milk of wonder.
His heart beat faster as Daisy’s white face came up to his own. He knew that when he kissed this girl, and forever wed his unutterable visions to her perishable breath, his mind would never romp again like the mind of God. So he waited, listening for a moment longer to the tuning-fork that had been struck upon a star. Then he kissed her. At his lips’ touch she blossomed for him like a flower and the incarnation was complete.
Through all he said, even through his appalling sentimentality, I was reminded of something—an elusive rhythm, a fragment of lost words, that I had heard somewhere a long time ago. For a moment a phrase tried to take shape in my mouth and my lips parted like a dumb man’s, as though there was more struggling upon them than a wisp of startled air. But they made no sound, and what I had almost remembered was uncommunicable forever.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I stayed late that night. The last of the guests had gone and the house was dark and silent. Gatsby appeared at last, his face strained and tired, as though he had been waiting for someone who never came. He came over to me at once, his eyes searching mine.

"Daisy didn't have a good time," he said. "She didn't like it. She said it was too much."

I saw at once that he was depressed, that the distance between him and Daisy had become a chasm. He was no longer the man who had stood on the dock with his arms outstretched toward the green light. He was a man who had lost something and was trying to find it again.

"I want her to tell him that she never loved him," he said. "That she never loved Tom. That she loved me. That she only loved me. Then it would be just as it was before. We could go back to Louisville and be married now."

I shook my head. "You can't repeat the past," I said.

"Can't repeat the past?" he cried incredulously. "Why of course you can! I'm going to fix everything just the way it was before. He'll be a very well-liked man, and I'll be a very well-liked man, and we'll be friends."

He talked a great deal about the past, about the way he had felt when he was young, about the way he had loved Daisy. He had always loved her, he said, and he had never stopped loving her. He had built his whole life around the idea of her, around the dream of her. He had made money, he had thrown parties, he had bought this house, all for her. And now he wanted to go back to the beginning, to the moment when he had first seen her, to the moment when he had first fallen in love with her.

He told me about the night five years ago when he had walked with her on a moonlit path in Louisville. The air had been cool and the leaves had been falling, and the moon had been full and bright. He had looked at her and seen in her face the reflection of his own soul. He had felt that the sidewalk was a ladder, and that he was climbing toward a higher realm, a realm that only he could reach. He had paused before kissing her, knowing that the moment he did, he would be binding his unutterable visions to her perishable breath, and that his god-like state would be over. But he had kissed her anyway, and in that moment, he had felt her blossom, and he had felt his dream come to life.

As he spoke, I felt a strange sense of recognition, as though I were remembering something I had once known but had long forgotten. It was a feeling of something lost, something that could never be found again. And yet, as I listened to Gatsby, I could not help but feel that he was right. That the past could be repeated. That it could be relived, if only for a moment. But I knew that it was not possible. That the past was gone, and that all we could do was live in the present and hope for the future. And so I said nothing, and I let him speak, and I let him dream.

events.title: Gatsby's Parties Cease and Staff Replaced
detailed_summary: Nick notices Gatsby's house is dark on a Saturday night, signaling the end of his extravagant parties.
Cars arriving at Gatsby's driveway turn away disappointed.
Concerned, Nick goes to Gatsby's house and encounters a rude, unfamiliar butler who confirms Gatsby isn't sick but offers no further information.
Nick learns from his housekeeper that Gatsby fired his entire staff a week prior and hired new ones, rumored not to be actual servants, who maintain secrecy and order supplies minimally.
Gatsby phones Nick the next day.
Gatsby confirms he fired his staff because he wanted people who wouldn't spread rumors, as Daisy frequently visits him in the afternoons.
Nick realizes Gatsby dismantled his entire social spectacle because Daisy disapproved.
Gatsby mentions the new staff are associates of Wolfshiem, possibly siblings who previously ran a hotel.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I see.”

events.text_segment:
It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over. Only gradually did I become aware that the automobiles which turned expectantly into his drive stayed for just a minute and then drove sulkily away. Wondering if he were sick I went over to find out—an unfamiliar butler with a villainous face squinted at me suspiciously from the door.
“Is Mr. Gatsby sick?”
“Nope.” After a pause he added “sir” in a dilatory, grudging way.
“I hadn’t seen him around, and I was rather worried. Tell him Mr. Carraway came over.”
“Who?” he demanded rudely.
“Carraway.”
“Carraway. All right, I’ll tell him.”
Abruptly he slammed the door.
My Finn informed me that Gatsby had dismissed every servant in his house a week ago and replaced them with half a dozen others, who never went into West Egg village to be bribed by the tradesmen, but ordered moderate supplies over the telephone. The grocery boy reported that the kitchen looked like a pigsty, and the general opinion in the village was that the new people weren’t servants at all.
Next day Gatsby called me on the phone.
“Going away?” I inquired.
“No, old sport.”
“I hear you fired all your servants.”
“I wanted somebody who wouldn’t gossip. Daisy comes over quite often—in the afternoons.”
So the whole caravansary had fallen in like a card house at the disapproval in her eyes.
“They’re some people Wolfshiem wanted to do something for. They’re all brothers and sisters. They used to run a small hotel.”
“I see.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was when curiosity about Gatsby was at its highest that the lights in his house failed to go on one Saturday night—and, as obscurely as it had begun, his career as Trimalchio was over. The next night and the next, the parties continued with diminished brilliance, and then they stopped altogether. The great house was dark and silent, and the long, white road shimmered in the moonlight. The cars that had once arrived in a steady stream now turned away, their occupants whispering of scandal or disillusionment. 

I went over to Gatsby's the next afternoon, curious to see what had become of the place. The front door was opened by a man I did not know, a tall, gaunt figure with a face like a dead man's. He looked at me with a kind of sullen hostility. 

"Mr. Gatsby isn't here," he said. 

"Is he sick?" I asked. 

"I don't know," he replied. 

I turned to go, but something in the man's manner made me hesitate. "Who are you?" I asked. 

"I'm the butler," he said. 

I had never seen him before. 

That night I asked my housekeeper, who is Finnish and has a curious habit of knowing everything that goes on in the neighborhood, if she had heard anything about Gatsby. 

"He fired all his servants a week ago," she said. "He got new ones from New York. They don't do much, but they keep things quiet. They don't talk, and they don't let people in unless they're wanted."

"Who are they?" I asked. 

"I don't know," she said. "But I heard they're from the same place as Wolfshiem."

The next day Gatsby called me on the phone. 

"I had to get rid of the old staff," he said. "They were always talking. I wanted people who wouldn't spread rumors. Daisy comes to see me in the afternoons, and I don't want her to be embarrassed."

"But why go to such extremes?" I asked. 

"Because I want to be sure she doesn't hear anything that might make her uncomfortable," he said. 

I realized then that Gatsby was not merely changing his servants—he was dismantling the whole elaborate show he had put on for the world. The parties, the lights, the music, the laughter—all of it had been a performance, and now the curtain had come down. 

"The new people are associates of Wolfshiem," he said. "They're brothers. They used to run a hotel in Chicago."

I said nothing. I was too stunned to speak. 

"They're good people," he added. "They understand discretion."

I could only imagine what that meant.

The parties stopped coming, the music stopped playing, and the laughter that had once echoed through the halls of West Egg fell silent. Gatsby, who had once been the life of the party, now became a ghost of his former self, retreating into the shadows of his own estate. The guests who had once flocked to his lavish gatherings, drawn by the allure of mystery and excess, now vanished like smoke, leaving behind only the remnants of a dream. Gatsby, like the ancient Roman Trimalchio, had played his role to the end, but without the audience, the performance was over. The lights in his house remained off, a silent signal that the show was done, and the curtain had fallen on the life he had so carefully constructed. In the end, Gatsby was left alone, not with the wealth or the love he had longed for, but with the quiet emptiness of a dream that had come to an end.

events.title: Invitation to Lunch Amidst Oppressive Heat
detailed_summary: Gatsby calls Nick at Daisy's request, inviting him to lunch at the Buchanans' house the following day, mentioning Miss Baker will also attend.
Daisy calls Nick shortly after, expressing relief that he accepted, making Nick sense that something significant is planned, possibly the confrontation Gatsby had previously mentioned.
The next day is described as unbearably hot, the peak of summer.
Nick travels by train through the intense heat, observing the discomfort of fellow passengers, including a woman who drops her purse.
Nick retrieves the purse for the woman but feels unjustly suspected by her and others nearby.
The train conductor complains about the heat, leaving a sweaty stain on Nick's ticket.
Nick reflects on the overpowering heat, questioning the significance of romance or emotion in such extreme weather.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!

events.text_segment:
He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker would be there. Half an hour later Daisy herself telephoned and seemed relieved to find that I was coming. Something was up. And yet I couldn’t believe that they would choose this occasion for a scene—especially for the rather harrowing scene that Gatsby had outlined in the garden.
The next day was broiling, almost the last, certainly the warmest, of the summer. As my train emerged from the tunnel into sunlight, only the hot whistles of the National Biscuit Company broke the simmering hush at noon. The straw seats of the car hovered on the edge of combustion; the woman next to me perspired delicately for a while into her white shirtwaist, and then, as her newspaper dampened under her fingers, lapsed despairingly into deep heat with a desolate cry. Her pocketbook slapped to the floor.
“Oh, my!” she gasped.
I picked it up with a weary bend and handed it back to her, holding it at arm’s length and by the extreme tip of the corners to indicate that I had no designs upon it—but everyone near by, including the woman, suspected me just the same.
“Hot!” said the conductor to familiar faces. “Some weather!… Hot!… Hot!… Hot!… Is it hot enough for you? Is it hot? Is it… ?”
My commutation ticket came back to me with a dark stain from his hand. That anyone should care in this heat whose flushed lips he kissed, whose head made damp the pyjama pocket over his heart!

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: He was calling up at Daisy’s request—would I come to lunch at her house tomorrow? Miss Baker will be there, he said. I agreed, and a few minutes later the telephone rang again. It was Daisy. She was so glad I had accepted. She had been afraid I might not. I could feel her excitement, her nervousness, as if something were about to happen. The next day was the hottest of the summer, the sun blazing down with a merciless intensity. I took the train out to West Egg, the heat pressing in on all sides. The car was packed with people sweating and fanning themselves with newspapers. A woman in a yellow dress dropped her purse, and I bent down to pick it up for her. She thanked me, but I could see the suspicion in her eyes, as if I might have taken something. The conductor, a grizzled man with a red face, muttered about the heat as he stamped my ticket, leaving a damp, sweaty mark on the paper. I sat back and looked out the window, watching the fields blur past in the heat. I wondered how anyone could feel anything—love, or excitement, or even fear—on a day like this, when the very air seemed to resist movement, to hold you down with its weight.

I was a little surprised, for I had not seen or heard from Daisy since the day of the accident, and I was not sure that she was calling me for any other reason than to be kind. But I agreed, of course, and the next afternoon I found myself at her house in East Egg, where the air was thick with the perfume of old money and the weight of unspoken things. Tom was there, too, and he greeted me with a curt nod, his presence a reminder of the world I did not belong to. Daisy, however, was radiant, her laughter light and effortless, as if nothing had changed. We sat in the garden, the sun warm on our backs, and for a moment, I almost believed that the past few weeks had been a dream. But the conversation was strained, and I could feel the tension beneath the surface, like a current just below the water. Gatsby was not there, but his absence was a constant presence, a shadow that hovered over every word and glance. Daisy spoke of him often, with a kind of wistful affection that made my heart ache. I could see the way she looked at me sometimes, as if she were trying to decide whether I was a friend or a threat. And I could see the way Tom watched her, his jaw tight, his eyes cold. I knew then that nothing was as it seemed, and that the world of Daisy and Tom was one of illusions and fragile facades. As the afternoon wore on, I felt more and more like an intruder, a ghost from the past who had no place in their carefully constructed lives. And yet, I could not bring myself to leave, not yet.

events.title: Tense Arrival and Pammy's Introduction at the Buchanans'
detailed_summary: Nick and Gatsby arrive at the Buchanans' house, hearing the phone ringing inside.
The butler answers the phone with a dismissive remark about the heat before greeting them.
The butler leads them into a cool, darkened room where Daisy and Jordan are reclining languidly on a couch, complaining about the heat.
Jordan greets Nick.
Tom's voice is heard on the phone in the hall; Jordan whispers to Nick that Tom's mistress is likely the caller.
Tom's voice rises in anger as he argues about selling his car.
Tom enters the room abruptly, greeting Gatsby with veiled hostility.
Daisy asks Tom to make cold drinks.
While Tom is out of the room, Daisy impulsively kisses Gatsby, murmuring that she loves him.
Jordan reminds them of her presence, and Daisy playfully suggests Jordan kiss Nick.
Daisy's daughter, Pammy, is brought in by her nurse.
Daisy fawns over the child, showing her off to Gatsby and Nick.
Gatsby appears surprised by the child's existence, looking at her intently.
Daisy comments on Pammy resembling her rather than Tom.
Pammy is quickly led away by the nurse as Tom returns with gin rickeys.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: … Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.

events.text_segment:
… Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door.
“The master’s body?” roared the butler into the mouthpiece. “I’m sorry, madame, but we can’t furnish it—it’s far too hot to touch this noon!”
What he really said was: “Yes… Yes… I’ll see.”
He set down the receiver and came toward us, glistening slightly, to take our stiff straw hats.
“Madame expects you in the salon!” he cried, needlessly indicating the direction. In this heat every extra gesture was an affront to the common store of life.
The room, shadowed well with awnings, was dark and cool. Daisy and Jordan lay upon an enormous couch, like silver idols weighing down their own white dresses against the singing breeze of the fans.
“We can’t move,” they said together.
Jordan’s fingers, powdered white over their tan, rested for a moment in mine.
“And Mr. Thomas Buchanan, the athlete?” I inquired.
Simultaneously I heard his voice, gruff, muffled, husky, at the hall telephone.
Gatsby stood in the centre of the crimson carpet and gazed around with fascinated eyes. Daisy watched him and laughed, her sweet, exciting laugh; a tiny gust of powder rose from her bosom into the air.
“The rumour is,” whispered Jordan, “that that’s Tom’s girl on the telephone.”
We were silent. The voice in the hall rose high with annoyance: “Very well, then, I won’t sell you the car at all… I’m under no obligations to you at all… and as for your bothering me about it at lunch time, I won’t stand that at all!”
“Holding down the receiver,” said Daisy cynically.
“No, he’s not,” I assured her. “It’s a bona-fide deal. I happen to know about it.”
Tom flung open the door, blocked out its space for a moment with his thick body, and hurried into the room.
“Mr. Gatsby!” He put out his broad, flat hand with well-concealed dislike. “I’m glad to see you, sir… Nick…”
“Make us a cold drink,” cried Daisy.
As he left the room again she got up and went over to Gatsby and pulled his face down, kissing him on the mouth.
“You know I love you,” she murmured.
“You forget there’s a lady present,” said Jordan.
Daisy looked around doubtfully.
“You kiss Nick too.”
“What a low, vulgar girl!”
“I don’t care!” cried Daisy, and began to clog on the brick fireplace. Then she remembered the heat and sat down guiltily on the couch just as a freshly laundered nurse leading a little girl came into the room.
“Bles-sed pre-cious,” she crooned, holding out her arms. “Come to your own mother that loves you.”
The child, relinquished by the nurse, rushed across the room and rooted shyly into her mother’s dress.
“The bles-sed pre-cious! Did mother get powder on your old yellowy hair? Stand up now, and say—How-de-do.”
Gatsby and I in turn leaned down and took the small reluctant hand. Afterward he kept looking at the child with surprise. I don’t think he had ever really believed in its existence before.
“I got dressed before luncheon,” said the child, turning eagerly to Daisy.
“That’s because your mother wanted to show you off.” Her face bent into the single wrinkle of the small white neck. “You dream, you. You absolute little dream.”
“Yes,” admitted the child calmly. “Aunt Jordan’s got on a white dress too.”
“How do you like mother’s friends?” Daisy turned her around so that she faced Gatsby. “Do you think they’re pretty?”
“Where’s Daddy?”
“She doesn’t look like her father,” explained Daisy. “She looks like me. She’s got my hair and shape of the face.”
Daisy sat back upon the couch. The nurse took a step forward and held out her hand.
“Come, Pammy.”
“Goodbye, sweetheart!”
With a reluctant backward glance the well-disciplined child held to her nurse’s hand and was pulled out the door, just as Tom came back, preceding four gin rickeys that clicked full of ice.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door. The butler, a man with a face like a wet sponge, answered it with a sigh and a muttered remark about the heat. He led us into a cool, darkened room where Daisy and Jordan were reclining on a couch, languid and pale, like flowers in a conservatory. Daisy looked up with a languid smile, and Jordan, with a flick of her cigarette, greeted me with a nod. The telephone was still ringing in the hall, and Tom’s voice, loud and angry, cut through the stillness. Jordan leaned toward me and whispered, “That’s Myrtle Wilson on the phone. He’s trying to get rid of her.”

Tom’s voice rose in a sharp, aggressive tone, and I could hear him arguing about selling his car. Then he came in, tall and brutal, his face flushed with heat and irritation. He nodded at Gatsby, but the gesture was stiff and unfriendly. Daisy, as if to smooth the air, asked Tom to make some cold drinks. He went out, and in the silence that followed, Daisy turned to Gatsby with a sudden, unguarded look in her eyes. She leaned forward and kissed him impulsively, murmuring, “I love you, just say the word and I’ll do anything.”

Jordan, with a sardonic smile, reminded them of her presence, and Daisy, with a laugh, suggested that Jordan kiss me. But the moment passed quickly. The nurse entered with Pammy, Daisy’s daughter, a small, golden-haired child with a doll in her arms. Daisy fawned over her, showing her off to Gatsby and me. Gatsby looked at the child with a strange, almost startled expression, as if he had not expected her to exist. Daisy, noticing his gaze, said, “She takes after me, doesn’t she?” The nurse, with a brisk efficiency, led Pammy away, and Tom returned with the drinks, the room settling once more into its uneasy calm.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: … Through the hall of the Buchanans’ house blew a faint wind, carrying the sound of the telephone bell out to Gatsby and me as we waited at the door. Gatsby’s face was pale and strained, his eyes fixed on the door as if he could will it to open. I could see the tension in his shoulders, the way his fingers twitched at his sides. He had waited for this moment for so long, and now it was here, and he was afraid to let it go. I wanted to say something to him, to offer some reassurance, but the words wouldn’t come. There was nothing I could say that would make this easier for him. The telephone bell rang again, and this time it was answered from within. A voice—Daisy’s voice—came through the door, hesitant, uncertain. Gatsby turned to me, his eyes wide with hope and fear. I could see the years of longing in his face, the dreams he had built around this woman, this house, this life. I had always known that Gatsby was chasing something more than Daisy herself, something more than love. He was chasing the past, the illusion of a perfect life that had been stolen from him. The door opened, and Daisy stood there, her face pale, her eyes red-rimmed. She looked at Gatsby, and for a moment, I thought I saw the old Daisy—the Daisy of his dreams—shine through. But then she looked at me, and the light in her eyes dimmed. She had changed, and so had the world around her. Gatsby stepped forward, and I could see the moment of decision in his face. He had come so far, risked so much, and now he was here, at the threshold of his dream. I stepped back, giving him space, knowing that whatever happened next was up to him. He reached out to her, and she reached back, and for a moment, it was as if time had stopped. But then the moment passed, and the reality of the situation settled in. The past could not be reclaimed, and the dream could not be made real. Gatsby had come to believe in the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock, in the idea that if he could just reach it, everything would be perfect. But the green light was just a light, and Daisy was just a woman. And Gatsby was just a man, flawed and human, with all the hopes and fears that come with being alive. As I watched them step inside, I felt a deep sadness settle over me. Gatsby had given everything for this moment, and now it was over. I knew that he would not leave the house the same man who had entered it. Something had changed, something had been lost. And as I walked away, I could not help but wonder if the dream had ever been real at all, or if it had always been just a mirage, shimmering on the horizon, just out of reach.

events.title: Luncheon Tension Culminates in a Trip to Town
detailed_summary: Gatsby nervously sips his drink.
Tom makes small talk about the weather and shows Gatsby the estate.
Gatsby points out his own house across the bay.
They have lunch in a darkened dining room, the mood strained despite attempts at gaiety.
Daisy despairs about the heat and the future, impulsively suggesting they all go to town.
While Tom talks to Gatsby about converting a garage, Daisy pointedly tells Gatsby he looks cool.
Daisy and Gatsby share an intense, exclusive gaze, which Tom observes.
Tom, visibly shocked and angered by the intimacy he witnessed, abruptly agrees to go to town.
Tom's agitation grows as he tries to hurry everyone along.
Daisy resists being rushed, asking for time for a cigarette, but Tom insists.
Daisy and Jordan go upstairs to prepare, leaving the men awkwardly waiting outside.
Gatsby attempts small talk with Tom about the stables.
Tom vents frustration about women's 'notions'.
Daisy calls down about drinks, and Tom goes inside to get whiskey.
Gatsby confides in Nick that he feels constrained in Tom's house.
Nick remarks on Daisy's indiscreet voice.
Gatsby suddenly declares her voice is 'full of money,' an insight Nick finds illuminating.
Tom returns with whiskey, followed by Daisy and Jordan dressed for the city.
Gatsby suggests taking his car, but Tom insists they swap cars, proposing he drive Gatsby's yellow car and Gatsby drive his coupé.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Gatsby took up his drink.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Well, you take my coupé and let me drive your car to town.”

events.text_segment:
Gatsby took up his drink.
“They certainly look cool,” he said, with visible tension.
We drank in long, greedy swallows.
“I read somewhere that the sun’s getting hotter every year,” said Tom genially. “It seems that pretty soon the earth’s going to fall into the sun—or wait a minute—it’s just the opposite—the sun’s getting colder every year.
“Come outside,” he suggested to Gatsby, “I’d like you to have a look at the place.”
I went with them out to the veranda. On the green Sound, stagnant in the heat, one small sail crawled slowly toward the fresher sea. Gatsby’s eyes followed it momentarily; he raised his hand and pointed across the bay.
“I’m right across from you.”
“So you are.”
Our eyes lifted over the rose-beds and the hot lawn and the weedy refuse of the dog-days alongshore. Slowly the white wings of the boat moved against the blue cool limit of the sky. Ahead lay the scalloped ocean and the abounding blessed isles.
“There’s sport for you,” said Tom, nodding. “I’d like to be out there with him for about an hour.”
We had luncheon in the dining-room, darkened too against the heat, and drank down nervous gaiety with the cold ale.
“What’ll we do with ourselves this afternoon?” cried Daisy, “and the day after that, and the next thirty years?”
“Don’t be morbid,” Jordan said. “Life starts all over again when it gets crisp in the fall.”
“But it’s so hot,” insisted Daisy, on the verge of tears, “and everything’s so confused. Let’s all go to town!”
Her voice struggled on through the heat, beating against it, moulding its senselessness into forms.
“I’ve heard of making a garage out of a stable,” Tom was saying to Gatsby, “but I’m the first man who ever made a stable out of a garage.”
“Who wants to go to town?” demanded Daisy insistently. Gatsby’s eyes floated toward her. “Ah,” she cried, “you look so cool.”
Their eyes met, and they stared together at each other, alone in space. With an effort she glanced down at the table.
“You always look so cool,” she repeated.
She had told him that she loved him, and Tom Buchanan saw. He was astounded. His mouth opened a little, and he looked at Gatsby, and then back at Daisy as if he had just recognized her as someone he knew a long time ago.
“You resemble the advertisement of the man,” she went on innocently. “You know the advertisement of the man—”
“All right,” broke in Tom quickly, “I’m perfectly willing to go to town. Come on—we’re all going to town.”
He got up, his eyes still flashing between Gatsby and his wife. No one moved.
“Come on!” His temper cracked a little. “What’s the matter, anyhow? If we’re going to town, let’s start.”
His hand, trembling with his effort at self-control, bore to his lips the last of his glass of ale. Daisy’s voice got us to our feet and out on to the blazing gravel drive.
“Are we just going to go?” she objected. “Like this? Aren’t we going to let anyone smoke a cigarette first?”
“Everybody smoked all through lunch.”
“Oh, let’s have fun,” she begged him. “It’s too hot to fuss.”
He didn’t answer.
“Have it your own way,” she said. “Come on, Jordan.”
They went upstairs to get ready while we three men stood there shuffling the hot pebbles with our feet. A silver curve of the moon hovered already in the western sky. Gatsby started to speak, changed his mind, but not before Tom wheeled and faced him expectantly.
“Have you got your stables here?” asked Gatsby with an effort.
“About a quarter of a mile down the road.”
“Oh.”
A pause.
“I don’t see the idea of going to town,” broke out Tom savagely. “Women get these notions in their heads—”
“Shall we take anything to drink?” called Daisy from an upper window.
“I’ll get some whisky,” answered Tom. He went inside.
Gatsby turned to me rigidly:
“I can’t say anything in his house, old sport.”
“She’s got an indiscreet voice,” I remarked. “It’s full of—” I hesitated.
“Her voice is full of money,” he said suddenly.
That was it. I’d never understood before. It was full of money—that was the inexhaustible charm that rose and fell in it, the jingle of it, the cymbals’ song of it… High in a white palace the king’s daughter, the golden girl…
Tom came out of the house wrapping a quart bottle in a towel, followed by Daisy and Jordan wearing small tight hats of metallic cloth and carrying light capes over their arms.
“Shall we all go in my car?” suggested Gatsby. He felt the hot, green leather of the seat. “I ought to have left it in the shade.”
“Is it standard shift?” demanded Tom.
“Yes.”
“Well, you take my coupé and let me drive your car to town.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Gatsby took up his drink. He had been drinking for some time, and his face was flushed and his eyes were bright. Tom, with the air of a man who is trying to be agreeable, made small talk about the weather and the estate. He showed Gatsby around, pointing out the various improvements he had made, but Gatsby seemed more interested in the view across the bay, where his own house was visible in the distance. They had lunch in a darkened dining room, the atmosphere strained despite Tom's attempts at gaiety. Daisy, overwhelmed by the heat and the weight of the future, expressed her despair and impulsively suggested they all go to town. While Tom and Gatsby discussed the possibility of converting a garage into a stable, Daisy, with a pointed remark, told Gatsby he looked cool. The moment was charged with tension as Daisy and Gatsby exchanged a long, intense gaze, one that seemed to exclude everyone else in the room. Tom, watching from the corner, was visibly shocked and angered by the intimacy he had just witnessed. He abruptly agreed to Daisy's suggestion, though his agitation was evident as he tried to hurry everyone along. Daisy, however, resisted being rushed, asking for time to take a cigarette, but Tom insisted. Daisy and Jordan went upstairs to prepare, leaving the men awkwardly waiting outside. Gatsby, trying to fill the silence, made small talk with Tom about the stables. Tom, frustrated, vented about women's 'notions' and the difficulty of managing them. Daisy called down about drinks, and Tom went inside to get whiskey. Gatsby, turning to Nick, confided that he felt constrained in Tom's house, as if the walls were closing in. Nick, observing Daisy's voice, remarked on its indiscreet quality. Gatsby, in a sudden moment of insight, said, 'Her voice is full of money,' a remark that struck Nick as illuminating. Tom returned with the whiskey, and soon after, Daisy and Jordan came down, dressed for the city. Gatsby suggested they take his car, but Tom insisted they swap cars, proposing he drive Gatsby's yellow car and Gatsby drive his coupé.

events.title: Tom Reveals Suspicions Driving Gatsby's Car
detailed_summary: Gatsby reluctantly agrees to Tom's car swap proposal after a weak objection about gas.
Tom makes a pointed remark about being able to buy anything at drugstores nowadays, which causes Gatsby visible unease.
Tom directs Daisy towards Gatsby's car, calling it a 'circus wagon'.
Daisy refuses, deciding to ride with Gatsby in Tom's coupé.
Tom, Jordan, and Nick get into Gatsby's yellow car, and Tom drives off quickly.
Tom immediately confronts Nick and Jordan, realizing they knew about Daisy and Gatsby.
Tom defensively claims to have 'second sight' and reveals he has been investigating Gatsby's past.
Jordan mocks Tom's claim of investigation.
Tom scoffs at the idea of Gatsby being an 'Oxford man,' pointing to his pink suit as evidence against it.
Jordan insists Gatsby did attend Oxford.
Tom dismisses it as perhaps a different Oxford.
Jordan questions Tom's snobbery, asking why he invited Gatsby if he disapproves.
Tom reveals Daisy invited Gatsby, mentioning she knew him before their marriage.
The group grows irritable and rides in silence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We were all irritable now with the fading ale, and aware of it we drove for a while in silence.

events.text_segment:
The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby.
“I don’t think there’s much gas,” he objected.
“Plenty of gas,” said Tom boisterously. He looked at the gauge. “And if it runs out I can stop at a drugstore. You can buy anything at a drugstore nowadays.”
A pause followed this apparently pointless remark. Daisy looked at Tom frowning, and an indefinable expression, at once definitely unfamiliar and vaguely recognizable, as if I had only heard it described in words, passed over Gatsby’s face.
“Come on, Daisy,” said Tom, pressing her with his hand toward Gatsby’s car. “I’ll take you in this circus wagon.”
He opened the door, but she moved out from the circle of his arm.
“You take Nick and Jordan. We’ll follow you in the coupé.”
She walked close to Gatsby, touching his coat with her hand. Jordan and Tom and I got into the front seat of Gatsby’s car, Tom pushed the unfamiliar gears tentatively, and we shot off into the oppressive heat, leaving them out of sight behind.
“Did you see that?” demanded Tom.
“See what?”
He looked at me keenly, realizing that Jordan and I must have known all along.
“You think I’m pretty dumb, don’t you?” he suggested. “Perhaps I am, but I have a—almost a second sight, sometimes, that tells me what to do. Maybe you don’t believe that, but science—”
He paused. The immediate contingency overtook him, pulled him back from the edge of theoretical abyss.
“I’ve made a small investigation of this fellow,” he continued. “I could have gone deeper if I’d known—”
“Do you mean you’ve been to a medium?” inquired Jordan humorously.
“What?” Confused, he stared at us as we laughed. “A medium?”
“About Gatsby.”
“About Gatsby! No, I haven’t. I said I’d been making a small investigation of his past.”
“And you found he was an Oxford man,” said Jordan helpfully.
“An Oxford man!” He was incredulous. “Like hell he is! He wears a pink suit.”
“Nevertheless he’s an Oxford man.”
“Oxford, New Mexico,” snorted Tom contemptuously, “or something like that.”
“Listen, Tom. If you’re such a snob, why did you invite him to lunch?” demanded Jordan crossly.
“Daisy invited him; she knew him before we were married—God knows where!”
We were all irritable now with the fading ale, and aware of it we drove for a while in silence.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby. He hesitated, his fingers tightening slightly on the edge of the table. "I don't think we should take the gas," he said weakly, as if the objection were more to the principle than the inconvenience. But Tom, with a smirk, waved it off. "It's all the same to me," he said. "You can have my car if you want it. I've got a new one at home." Gatsby's face flickered with something like alarm, but he nodded. "All right," he said, "if you say so." Tom's voice took on a mocking tone as he added, "You can get anything at a drugstore nowadays, I suppose." Gatsby's smile faltered. He looked away, his expression unreadable. "Come on, Daisy," Tom said, gesturing toward Gatsby's car. "It's a circus wagon, but it'll do." Daisy shook her head. "I'd rather ride with Jay," she said, her voice firm. "I know his car better." Tom's jaw tightened, but he said nothing. He climbed into Gatsby's yellow car, followed by Nick and Jordan. Tom took the wheel and, without a word, pulled away from the curb. The car lurched forward, and Tom's voice broke the silence. "You knew, didn't you?" he said, turning to Nick and Jordan. "You knew about Daisy and Gatsby." Jordan met his gaze with a cool, unflinching stare. "What's it to you?" she asked. Tom's hands gripped the wheel. "I've got second sight," he said. "I've been looking into Gatsby's past. You think he's some kind of Oxford man?" He gestured toward Gatsby's pink suit. "Look at that. That's not Oxford. That's a costume." Jordan leaned forward. "He did go to Oxford," she said. "He was there after the war." Tom scoffed. "Maybe it was a different Oxford," he said. "I don't know. Maybe it was in Missouri." Jordan's eyes narrowed. "Why did you invite him then?" she asked. "If you're so sure he's a fraud, why bring him into the mix?" Tom's face darkened. "Daisy invited him," he said. "She knew him before she ever met me." The car fell into silence, the tension thick and unspoken. The city lights blurred past them as Tom drove on, the weight of the past pressing down on them all.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The suggestion was distasteful to Gatsby. He turned away from Jordan and looked out at the water, his face shadowed with something that might have been disappointment or anger. “I wouldn’t ask you to do that,” he said finally, his voice low and quiet, as if he were speaking more to himself than to her. “I’ve waited five years for this, and I’m not going to let it slip away because of something that happened a long time ago.”

Jordan looked at him, her expression unreadable. “You think you can just rewrite the past, Jay? You think you can go back and change it?”

Gatsby shook his head. “I don’t want to change it. I just want to have her again. Just for a little while. That’s all I’ve ever wanted.”

There was a silence between them, the kind that stretched and filled the space with unspoken things. The wind had picked up, and the waves lapped gently against the dock, as if the sea itself were listening.

“Do you really believe she’s still the same person?” Jordan asked, her voice softer now, almost sympathetic.

Gatsby’s eyes were fixed on the water. “She has to be. She has to be.”

Jordan sighed and leaned back against the dock. “You’re chasing a dream, Jay. And dreams don’t come true the way you think they will.”

Gatsby didn’t respond. He just stood there, staring at the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock, as if it were the only thing keeping him grounded in the world. The dream was still there, glowing faintly in the distance, and he wasn’t ready to let it go.

The wind carried the scent of salt and something else—something bittersweet, like the end of a summer that had never really ended. Gatsby had built his life around this one moment, this one hope, and he wasn’t about to let it slip away now. Not when he was so close. Not when the dream was still within reach.

events.title: Confrontation and Revelation at Wilson's Garage
detailed_summary: Approaching the valley of ashes, Nick remembers Gatsby's comment about gas.
Tom dismisses concerns about fuel but Jordan insists they stop at Wilson's garage due to the heat.
Tom brakes abruptly at the garage.
Wilson emerges looking ill and weak.
Tom impatiently demands gas.
Wilson explains he's been sick all day and needs money badly, inquiring about buying Tom's old car.
Wilson mentions his plan to take his wife and move West.
Tom is startled to hear Myrtle wants to go West.
Wilson reveals he is forcing Myrtle to leave, having 'wised up to something funny' recently, implying knowledge of her affair.
As Gatsby's coupé (carrying Gatsby and Daisy) drives past, Myrtle looks down from an upper window.
Nick observes Myrtle's face contort with jealous rage, realizing she assumes Jordan, riding with Tom, is Daisy.
Nick reflects on the parallel discoveries of infidelity made by Tom and Wilson, noting the profound difference sickness makes.
Tom promises to send his old car over to Wilson the next day.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “I’ll let you have that car,” said Tom.

events.text_segment:
Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline.
“We’ve got enough to get us to town,” said Tom.
“But there’s a garage right here,” objected Jordan. “I don’t want to get stalled in this baking heat.”
Tom threw on both brakes impatiently, and we slid to an abrupt dusty stop under Wilson’s sign. After a moment the proprietor emerged from the interior of his establishment and gazed hollow-eyed at the car.
“Let’s have some gas!” cried Tom roughly. “What do you think we stopped for—to admire the view?”
“I’m sick,” said Wilson without moving. “Been sick all day.”
“What’s the matter?”
“I’m all run down.”
“Well, shall I help myself?” Tom demanded. “You sounded well enough on the phone.”
With an effort Wilson left the shade and support of the doorway and, breathing hard, unscrewed the cap of the tank. In the sunlight his face was green.
“I didn’t mean to interrupt your lunch,” he said. “But I need money pretty bad, and I was wondering what you were going to do with your old car.”
“How do you like this one?” inquired Tom. “I bought it last week.”
“It’s a nice yellow one,” said Wilson, as he strained at the handle.
“Like to buy it?”
“Big chance,” Wilson smiled faintly. “No, but I could make some money on the other.”
“What do you want money for, all of a sudden?”
“I’ve been here too long. I want to get away. My wife and I want to go West.”
“Your wife does,” exclaimed Tom, startled.
“She’s been talking about it for ten years.” He rested for a moment against the pump, shading his eyes. “And now she’s going whether she wants to or not. I’m going to get her away.”
The coupé flashed by us with a flurry of dust and the flash of a waving hand.
“What do I owe you?” demanded Tom harshly.
“I just got wised up to something funny the last two days,” remarked Wilson. “That’s why I want to get away. That’s why I been bothering you about the car.”
“What do I owe you?”
“Dollar twenty.”
The relentless beating heat was beginning to confuse me and I had a bad moment there before I realized that so far his suspicions hadn’t alighted on Tom. He had discovered that Myrtle had some sort of life apart from him in another world, and the shock had made him physically sick. I stared at him and then at Tom, who had made a parallel discovery less than an hour before—and it occurred to me that there was no difference between men, in intelligence or race, so profound as the difference between the sick and the well. Wilson was so sick that he looked guilty, unforgivably guilty—as if he had just got some poor girl with child.
“I’ll let you have that car,” said Tom.

Tom braked suddenly, and Wilson came out, looking sick and weak and rather dazed. He stood in the doorway, wiping his forehead with a red bandana, and Tom impatiently demanded gas. Wilson explained that he had been sick all day and needed money badly. He asked if Tom would sell him his old car, and Tom, with a sort of brutal indifference, said he would send it over the next day. Wilson, in a low voice, mentioned that he was going to take his wife and move West. Tom was startled. He had not known that Myrtle wanted to go West. Wilson, with a strange, bitter smile, said he had wised up to something funny lately. He was going to force Myrtle to leave. As Gatsby’s coupé passed, Myrtle looked down from an upper window, her face contorted with jealous rage, thinking that Jordan, riding with Tom, was Daisy. I saw the awful, temporary difference that a moment’s discovery could make, and I thought of the parallel discoveries that Tom and Wilson had both made, and how profoundly the sickness had changed them both. Tom, with a careless gesture, promised to send his old car over the next day.

Then as Doctor T. J. Eckleburg’s faded eyes came into sight down the road, I remembered Gatsby’s caution about gasoline. I had been driving for some time, the car moving steadily along the desolate stretch of highway that separated West Egg from the Valley of Ashes. The air was thick with the acrid scent of industrial waste, and the landscape was bleak, a wasteland of soot and dust where the poor toiled in the shadows of the wealthy. Gatsby had warned me about the gasoline, though I had not fully understood his concern at the time. Perhaps it was a metaphor, or perhaps it was a literal warning about the dangers of excess, of the way things could go wrong when one pushed too hard, too fast, toward an impossible dream.

The billboard loomed ahead, its eyes watching silently, a silent judge over the moral decay of the world below. I thought of Gatsby, of his grand parties and his unshakable belief in the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock. He had always been a man of dreams, a man who believed in the power of reinvention, who thought that wealth and charm could erase the past and rewrite the future. But the world was not so kind. The world was filled with people like Tom Buchanan, who clung to their status and their prejudices, and people like Wilson, who were crushed beneath the weight of the system.

I had seen Gatsby’s face that night, the night of the accident, and I had known then that something had changed. The dream was slipping away, dissolving into the very ashes that surrounded us. He had loved Daisy with a passion that was almost tragic, a love that was not just for her, but for the idea of her, for the life she represented. And in the end, that love had been his undoing.

As I passed the billboard, I felt a strange sense of loss. Gatsby was gone, and with him, a part of the illusion that had once seemed so real. The world had moved on, and the people who had once filled his parties had long since forgotten his name. Only the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg remained, watching over the valley, a silent reminder of the moral emptiness that lay beneath the glittering surface of the American Dream.

I drove on, the road stretching out before me, and I wondered if anyone else had ever felt the weight of those eyes, or if they were simply a part of the landscape, a relic of a bygone era. But I knew that for Gatsby, they had been more than that. They had been a symbol, a silent witness to the tragedy of a man who had reached too far, who had believed too much, and who had paid the price for his dreams.

events.text_segment:
That locality was always vaguely disquieting, even in the broad glare of afternoon, and now I turned my head as though I had been warned of something behind. Over the ash-heaps the giant eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg kept their vigil, but I perceived, after a moment, that other eyes were regarding us with peculiar intensity from less than twenty feet away.
In one of the windows over the garage the curtains had been moved aside a little, and Myrtle Wilson was peering down at the car. So engrossed was she that she had no consciousness of being observed, and one emotion after another crept into her face like objects into a slowly developing picture. Her expression was curiously familiar—it was an expression I had often seen on women’s faces, but on Myrtle Wilson’s face it seemed purposeless and inexplicable until I realized that her eyes, wide with jealous terror, were fixed not on Tom, but on Jordan Baker, whom she took to be his wife.
There is no confusion like the confusion of a simple mind, and as we drove away Tom was feeling the hot whips of panic. His wife and his mistress, until an hour ago secure and inviolate, were slipping precipitately from his control. Instinct made him step on the accelerator with the double purpose of overtaking Daisy and leaving Wilson behind, and we sped along toward Astoria at fifty miles an hour, until, among the spidery girders of the elevated, we came in sight of the easygoing blue coupé.
“Those big movies around Fiftieth Street are cool,” suggested Jordan. “I love New York on summer afternoons when everyone’s away. There’s something very sensuous about it—overripe, as if all sorts of funny fruits were going to fall into your hands.”
The word “sensuous” had the effect of further disquieting Tom, but before he could invent a protest the coupé came to a stop, and Daisy signalled us to draw up alongside.
“Where are we going?” she cried.
“How about the movies?”
“It’s so hot,” she complained. “You go. We’ll ride around and meet you after.” With an effort her wit rose faintly. “We’ll meet you on some corner. I’ll be the man smoking two cigarettes.”
“We can’t argue about it here,” Tom said impatiently, as a truck gave out a cursing whistle behind us. “You follow me to the south side of Central Park, in front of the Plaza.”
Several times he turned his head and looked back for their car, and if the traffic delayed them he slowed up until they came into sight. I think he was afraid they would dart down a side-street and out of his life forever.
But they didn’t. And we all took the less explicable step of engaging the parlour of a suite in the Plaza Hotel.
The prolonged and tumultuous argument that ended by herding us into that room eludes me, though I have a sharp physical memory that, in the course of it, my underwear kept climbing like a damp snake around my legs and intermittent beads of sweat raced cool across my back. The notion originated with Daisy’s suggestion that we hire five bathrooms and take cold baths, and then assumed more tangible form as “a place to have a mint julep.” Each of us said over and over that it was a “crazy idea”—we all talked at once to a baffled clerk and thought, or pretended to think, that we were being very funny…
The room was large and stifling, and, though it was already four o’clock, opening the windows admitted only a gust of hot shrubbery from the Park. Daisy went to the mirror and stood with her back to us, fixing her hair.
“It’s a swell suite,” whispered Jordan respectfully, and everyone laughed.
“Open another window,” commanded Daisy, without turning around.
“There aren’t any more.”
“Well, we’d better telephone for an axe—”
“The thing to do is to forget about the heat,” said Tom impatiently. “You make it ten times worse by crabbing about it.”
He unrolled the bottle of whisky from the towel and put it on the table.
“Why not let her alone, old sport?” remarked Gatsby. “You’re the one that wanted to come to town.”
There was a moment of silence. The telephone book slipped from its nail and splashed to the floor, whereupon Jordan whispered, “Excuse me”—but this time no one laughed.
“I’ll pick it up,” I offered.
“I’ve got it.” Gatsby examined the parted string, muttered “Hum!” in an interested way, and tossed the book on a chair.
“That’s a great expression of yours, isn’t it?” said Tom sharply.
“What is?”
“All this ‘old sport’ business. Where’d you pick that up?”
“Now see here, Tom,” said Daisy, turning around from the mirror, “if you’re going to make personal remarks I won’t stay here a minute. Call up and order some ice for the mint julep.”
As Tom took up the receiver the compressed heat exploded into sound and we were listening to the portentous chords of Mendelssohn’s Wedding March from the ballroom below.
“Imagine marrying anybody in this heat!” cried Jordan dismally.
“Still—I was married in the middle of June,” Daisy remembered. “Louisville in June! Somebody fainted. Who was it fainted, Tom?”
“Biloxi,” he answered shortly.
“A man named Biloxi. ‘Blocks’ Biloxi, and he made boxes—that’s a fact—and he was from Biloxi, Tennessee.”
“They carried him into my house,” appended Jordan, “because we lived just two doors from the church. And he stayed three weeks, until Daddy told him he had to get out. The day after he left Daddy died.” After a moment she added as if she might have sounded irreverent, “There wasn’t any connection.”
“I used to know a Bill Biloxi from Memphis,” I remarked.
“That was his cousin. I knew his whole family history before he left. He gave me an aluminium putter that I use today.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
That locality was always vaguely disquieting, even in the broad glare of afternoon, and now I turned my head as though I had been warned of something behind. The eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg were perched like a pair of enormous yellow spectacles above the only available entrance to the valley of ashes. They looked out of no face, but, as you passed, you felt that they were considering you. I glanced back at Myrtle, who was watching us with a kind of fascinated horror, and then we drove on toward the city.

Tom was driving with a reckless, desperate energy, as though he were trying to outpace his own thoughts. He had lost control of both Daisy and Myrtle, and the realization was eating at him. We caught up with Gatsby and Daisy, who were waiting at a red light, and Jordan suggested we go to a movie in the cool theater. Daisy, however, complained about the heat and suggested we separate. Tom refused to hear of it. He insisted we all go to the Plaza Hotel, and he kept Gatsby's car in sight with a kind of anxious vigilance, as if afraid they might vanish into the city.

We ended up in a stifling suite at the Plaza, the kind of room that seemed to have been designed to make people sweat. Daisy tried to fix her hair, but the heat made it impossible. Tom, in a fit of irritation, told us all to stop moaning about the heat and poured out a round of whiskey. Gatsby, standing by the window, turned to Tom and said, "You asked me to come here, so don't try to push me away now." The room fell into a tense silence.

Tom, emboldened by the whiskey, turned on Gatsby and asked, "What's this 'old sport' business?" Daisy, sensing the danger, intervened. "Tom, please," she said, "don't make personal remarks. Just order some ice." As Tom went to the phone, the Wedding March from Mendelssohn drifted up from a wedding reception downstairs. It was a cruel irony, and we all sat there, listening, as if the music were mocking us. We talked about Daisy and Tom's wedding, and how Biloxi had once been a guest at the ceremony, a man who had once loved Daisy and had been forgotten in the years since.

events.text_segment:
The music had died down as the ceremony began and now a long cheer floated in at the window, followed by intermittent cries of “Yea—ea—ea!” and finally by a burst of jazz as the dancing began.
“We’re getting old,” said Daisy. “If we were young we’d rise and dance.”
“Remember Biloxi,” Jordan warned her. “Where’d you know him, Tom?”
“Biloxi?” He concentrated with an effort. “I didn’t know him. He was a friend of Daisy’s.”
“He was not,” she denied. “I’d never seen him before. He came down in the private car.”
“Well, he said he knew you. He said he was raised in Louisville. Asa Bird brought him around at the last minute and asked if we had room for him.”
Jordan smiled.
“He was probably bumming his way home. He told me he was president of your class at Yale.”
Tom and I looked at each other blankly.
“Biloxi?”
“First place, we didn’t have any president—”
Gatsby’s foot beat a short, restless tattoo and Tom eyed him suddenly.
“By the way, Mr. Gatsby, I understand you’re an Oxford man.”
“Not exactly.”
“Oh, yes, I understand you went to Oxford.”
“Yes—I went there.”
A pause. Then Tom’s voice, incredulous and insulting:
“You must have gone there about the time Biloxi went to New Haven.”
Another pause. A waiter knocked and came in with crushed mint and ice but the silence was unbroken by his “thank you” and the soft closing of the door. This tremendous detail was to be cleared up at last.
“I told you I went there,” said Gatsby.
“I heard you, but I’d like to know when.”
“It was in nineteen-nineteen, I only stayed five months. That’s why I can’t really call myself an Oxford man.”
Tom glanced around to see if we mirrored his unbelief. But we were all looking at Gatsby.
“It was an opportunity they gave to some of the officers after the armistice,” he continued. “We could go to any of the universities in England or France.”
I wanted to get up and slap him on the back. I had one of those renewals of complete faith in him that I’d experienced before.
Daisy rose, smiling faintly, and went to the table.
“Open the whisky, Tom,” she ordered, “and I’ll make you a mint julep. Then you won’t seem so stupid to yourself… Look at the mint!”
“Wait a minute,” snapped Tom, “I want to ask Mr. Gatsby one more question.”
“Go on,” Gatsby said politely.
“What kind of a row are you trying to cause in my house anyhow?”
They were out in the open at last and Gatsby was content.
“He isn’t causing a row,” Daisy looked desperately from one to the other. “You’re causing a row. Please have a little self-control.”
“Self-control!” repeated Tom incredulously. “I suppose the latest thing is to sit back and let Mr. Nobody from Nowhere make love to your wife. Well, if that’s the idea you can count me out… Nowadays people begin by sneering at family life and family institutions, and next they’ll throw everything overboard and have intermarriage between black and white.”
Flushed with his impassioned gibberish, he saw himself standing alone on the last barrier of civilization.
“We’re all white here,” murmured Jordan.
“I know I’m not very popular. I don’t give big parties. I suppose you’ve got to make your house into a pigsty in order to have any friends—in the modern world.”
Angry as I was, as we all were, I was tempted to laugh whenever he opened his mouth. The transition from libertine to prig was so complete.
“I’ve got something to tell you, old sport—” began Gatsby. But Daisy guessed at his intention.
“Please don’t!” she interrupted helplessly. “Please let’s all go home. Why don’t we all go home?”
“That’s a good idea,” I got up. “Come on, Tom. Nobody wants a drink.”
“I want to know what Mr. Gatsby has to tell me.”
“Your wife doesn’t love you,” said Gatsby. “She’s never loved you. She loves me.”
“You must be crazy!” exclaimed Tom automatically.
Gatsby sprang to his feet, vivid with excitement.
“She never loved you, do you hear?” he cried. “She only married you because I was poor and she was tired of waiting for me. It was a terrible mistake, but in her heart she never loved anyone except me!”
At this point Jordan and I tried to go, but Tom and Gatsby insisted with competitive firmness that we remain—as though neither of them had anything to conceal and it would be a privilege to partake vicariously of their emotions.
“Sit down, Daisy,” Tom’s voice groped unsuccessfully for the paternal note. “What’s been going on? I want to hear all about it.”
“I told you what’s been going on,” said Gatsby. “Going on for five years—and you didn’t know.”
Tom turned to Daisy sharply.
“You’ve been seeing this fellow for five years?”
“Not seeing,” said Gatsby. “No, we couldn’t meet. But both of us loved each other all that time, old sport, and you didn’t know. I used to laugh sometimes”—but there was no laughter in his eyes—“to think that you didn’t know.”
“Oh—that’s all.” Tom tapped his thick fingers together like a clergyman and leaned back in his chair.
“You’re crazy!” he exploded. “I can’t speak about what happened five years ago, because I didn’t know Daisy then—and I’ll be damned if I see how you got within a mile of her unless you brought the groceries to the back door. But all the rest of that’s a God damned lie. Daisy loved me when she married me and she loves me now.”
“No,” said Gatsby, shaking his head.
“She does, though. The trouble is that sometimes she gets foolish ideas in her head and doesn’t know what she’s doing.” He nodded sagely. “And what’s more, I love Daisy too. Once in a while I go off on a spree and make a fool of myself, but I always come back, and in my heart I love her all the time.”
“You’re revolting,” said Daisy. She turned to me, and her voice, dropping an octave lower, filled the room with thrilling scorn: “Do you know why we left Chicago? I’m surprised that they didn’t treat you to the story of that little spree.”
Gatsby walked over and stood beside her.
“Daisy, that’s all over now,” he said earnestly. “It doesn’t matter any more. Just tell him the truth—that you never loved him—and it’s all wiped out forever.”
She looked at him blindly. “Why—how could I love him—possibly?”
“You never loved him.”
She hesitated. Her eyes fell on Jordan and me with a sort of appeal, as though she realized at last what she was doing—and as though she had never, all along, intended doing anything at all. But it was done now. It was too late.
“I never loved him,” she said, with perceptible reluctance.
“Not at Kapiolani?” demanded Tom suddenly.
“No.”
From the ballroom beneath, muffled and suffocating chords were drifting up on hot waves of air.
“Not that day I carried you down from the Punch Bowl to keep your shoes dry?” There was a husky tenderness in his tone… “Daisy?”
“Please don’t.” Her voice was cold, but the rancour was gone from it. She looked at Gatsby. “There, Jay,” she said—but her hand as she tried to light a cigarette was trembling. Suddenly she threw the cigarette and the burning match on the carpet.
“Oh, you want too much!” she cried to Gatsby. “I love you now—isn’t that enough? I can’t help what’s past.” She began to sob helplessly. “I did love him once—but I loved you too.”
Gatsby’s eyes opened and closed.
“You loved me too?” he repeated.
“Even that’s a lie,” said Tom savagely. “She didn’t know you were alive. Why—there’s things between Daisy and me that you’ll never know, things that neither of us can ever forget.”
The words seemed to bite physically into Gatsby.
“I want to speak to Daisy alone,” he insisted. “She’s all excited now—”
“Even alone I can’t say I never loved Tom,” she admitted in a pitiful voice. “It wouldn’t be true.”
“Of course it wouldn’t,” agreed Tom.
She turned to her husband.
“As if it mattered to you,” she said.
“Of course it matters. I’m going to take better care of you from now on.”
“You don’t understand,” said Gatsby, with a touch of panic. “You’re not going to take care of her any more.”
“I’m not?” Tom opened his eyes wide and laughed. He could afford to control himself now. “Why’s that?”
“Daisy’s leaving you.”
“Nonsense.”
“I am, though,” she said with a visible effort.
“She’s not leaving me!” Tom’s words suddenly leaned down over Gatsby. “Certainly not for a common swindler who’d have to steal the ring he put on her finger.”
“I won’t stand this!” cried Daisy. “Oh, please let’s get out.”
“Who are you, anyhow?” broke out Tom. “You’re one of that bunch that hangs around with Meyer Wolfshiem—that much I happen to know. I’ve made a little investigation into your affairs—and I’ll carry it further tomorrow.”
“You can suit yourself about that, old sport,” said Gatsby steadily.
“I found out what your ‘drugstores’ were.” He turned to us and spoke rapidly. “He and this Wolfshiem bought up a lot of side-street drugstores here and in Chicago and sold grain alcohol over the counter. That’s one of his little stunts. I picked him for a bootlegger the first time I saw him, and I wasn’t far wrong.”
“What about it?” said Gatsby politely. “I guess your friend Walter Chase wasn’t too proud to come in on it.”
“And you left him in the lurch, didn’t you? You let him go to jail for a month over in New Jersey. God! You ought to hear Walter on the subject of you.”
“He came to us dead broke. He was very glad to pick up some money, old sport.”
“Don’t you call me ‘old sport’!” cried Tom. Gatsby said nothing. “Walter could have you up on the betting laws too, but Wolfshiem scared him into shutting his mouth.”
That unfamiliar yet recognizable look was back again in Gatsby’s face.
“That drugstore business was just small change,” continued Tom slowly, “but you’ve got something on now that Walter’s afraid to tell me about.”
I glanced at Daisy, who was staring terrified between Gatsby and her husband, and at Jordan, who had begun to balance an invisible but absorbing object on the tip of her chin. Then I turned back to Gatsby—and was startled at his expression. He looked—and this is said in all contempt for the babbled slander of his garden—as if he had “killed a man.” For a moment the set of his face could be described in just that fantastic way.
It passed, and he began to talk excitedly to Daisy, denying everything, defending his name against accusations that had not been made. But with every word she was drawing further and further into herself, so he gave that up, and only the dead dream fought on as the afternoon slipped away, trying to touch what was no longer tangible, struggling unhappily, undespairingly, toward that lost voice across the room.
The voice begged again to go.

Gatsby demanded to speak to Daisy alone, but she admitted, pitifully, that she could not truthfully say she never loved Tom. Tom asserted his intention to take better care of Daisy. Gatsby panicked, stating Daisy was leaving Tom.

Tom laughed, disbelieving, until Daisy confirmed it with effort. Tom furiously attacked Gatsby, calling him a bootlegger and referencing his association with Wolfshiem and shady drugstore deals. Gatsby attempted to defend himself but appeared shaken, looking as if he had “killed a man.” Daisy grew increasingly withdrawn and terrified as Gatsby denied Tom’s accusations. Gatsby’s dream seemed to die as Daisy lost her resolve.
