The air was thick with the scent of perfume and the sound of laughter, a perfect blend of elegance and exuberance. Gatsby stood at the center of it all, his eyes gleaming with a mixture of pride and anticipation. He had worked so hard to create this moment, to bring together the people he had longed to impress, to prove to the world that he was more than just a self-made man. He was a king among men, a dreamer who had turned his dreams into reality. The guests, dressed in their finest attire, moved gracefully across the dance floor, their feet tapping to the rhythm of the music. Some couples twirled in perfect harmony, while others simply swayed, lost in the moment. The atmosphere was electric, charged with the energy of possibility and the thrill of the unknown. Gatsby watched them with a mixture of joy and melancholy, his thoughts drifting to the past, to the days when he was just a young man with a dream and a heart full of hope. He had come a long way since then, but the dream was still alive, still burning within him. He had always believed that if he could just reach the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock, if he could just win her back, then everything would be perfect. But as he looked around the room, he realized that perfection was an illusion, a fleeting moment that could never truly be captured. The music swelled, and the guests began to move with more intensity, their movements more passionate, more alive. Gatsby felt a surge of emotion, a longing for something more than just the party, more than just the wealth and the status. He wanted love, true love, the kind that could withstand the test of time. He wanted to believe that Daisy still loved him, that she had never truly moved on. But deep down, he knew that the past was gone, and that the only thing he could do was to create a new future. The party continued, the music never stopping, the laughter never fading. Gatsby moved through the crowd, greeting his guests with a smile, but his heart was heavy with the weight of his unfulfilled dreams. He had everything he had ever wanted, yet he felt as if he were missing something essential, something that could never be replaced. The party was a success, a testament to his wealth and his power, but it was also a reminder of the emptiness that lay beneath the surface. As the night wore on, the guests began to thin out, some leaving to return to their own lives, while others stayed, drawn to the magic of the moment. Gatsby remained, standing at the edge of the dance floor, watching as the last of the dancers took their final steps. The music slowed, the lights dimmed, and the room was filled with a sense of quiet anticipation. Gatsby took a deep breath, the weight of the night settling on his shoulders. He had given everything to this party, to this moment, and yet he felt as if he had gained nothing in return. The green light at the end of Daisy’s dock still flickered in his mind, a symbol of the dream that had driven him forward, a dream that was now slipping through his fingers. He had always believed that if he could just reach it, if he could just touch it, then everything would be okay. But now, as he stood alone in the quiet of the night, he realized that the dream was just that—a dream, a fantasy that could never truly be realized. The party was over, the music had stopped, and the guests had gone. Gatsby stood alone, the echoes of the night still lingering in the air. He looked out at the dark water, the green light still shining in the distance, and he felt a sense of peace wash over him. Perhaps it was time to let go, to stop chasing the past and to start living in the present. The dream had brought him this far, but it was time to create a new dream, one that was his own, one that was real. He turned away from the window, the weight on his shoulders lighter now, and stepped into the night, ready to face whatever lay ahead.

events.title: Tom Reasserts Control and Nick Reflects on Turning Thirty
detailed_summary: Daisy pleads to leave, her courage gone.
Tom, sensing victory, magnanimously tells Daisy to drive home with Gatsby in Gatsby's car.
He dismisses Gatsby's 'presumptuous little flirtation' as over.
Daisy and Gatsby leave wordlessly.
Tom prepares to leave, offering Nick and Jordan the unopened whiskey.
Nick declines, suddenly remembering it is his thirtieth birthday.
Nick reflects on entering a new decade, anticipating loneliness and diminished prospects.
Driving back to Long Island with Tom and Jordan, Nick feels detached from Tom's exultant talk.
He finds some comfort in Jordan's presence beside him as they cross the bridge, momentarily forgetting the weight of turning thirty.
Nick frames their journey back as driving 'toward death through the cooling twilight'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So we drove on toward death through the cooling twilight.

events.text_segment:
“Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.”
Her frightened eyes told that whatever intentions, whatever courage she had had, were definitely gone.
“You two start on home, Daisy,” said Tom. “In Mr. Gatsby’s car.”
She looked at Tom, alarmed now, but he insisted with magnanimous scorn.
“Go on. He won’t annoy you. I think he realizes that his presumptuous little flirtation is over.”
They were gone, without a word, snapped out, made accidental, isolated, like ghosts, even from our pity.
After a moment Tom got up and began wrapping the unopened bottle of whisky in the towel.
“Want any of this stuff? Jordan?… Nick?”
I didn’t answer.
“Nick?” He asked again.
“What?”
“Want any?”
“No… I just remembered that today’s my birthday.”
I was thirty. Before me stretched the portentous, menacing road of a new decade.
It was seven o’clock when we got into the coupé with him and started for Long Island. Tom talked incessantly, exulting and laughing, but his voice was as remote from Jordan and me as the foreign clamour on the sidewalk or the tumult of the elevated overhead. Human sympathy has its limits, and we were content to let all their tragic arguments fade with the city lights behind. Thirty—the promise of a decade of loneliness, a thinning list of single men to know, a thinning briefcase of enthusiasm, thinning hair. But there was Jordan beside me, who, unlike Daisy, was too wise ever to carry well-forgotten dreams from age to age. As we passed over the dark bridge her wan face fell lazily against my coat’s shoulder and the formidable stroke of thirty died away with the reassuring pressure of her hand.
So we drove on toward death through the cooling twilight.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.”

Daisy’s voice was low and trembling, but there was a finality in it that made Tom stop. He looked at her, then at Gatsby, and for a moment the room seemed to hold its breath. Tom’s face was a mask of smug triumph.

“Well,” he said, “I think it’s time you went home, Daisy. You can drive with this young man.” He gestured toward Gatsby with a careless hand, as if he were swatting away a fly. “It’s been a delightful little flirtation, but I think it’s over now.”

Daisy didn’t answer. She only looked at Gatsby, her eyes wide and uncertain. Gatsby, for once, seemed to have no words. He simply nodded, and Daisy, with a small, wordless movement, followed him toward the door.

Tom turned to Nick and Jordan, offering the unopened bottle of whiskey with a flourish. “You two can finish this,” he said, already heading for the door. “I’ve got a meeting in the morning.”

Nick took the bottle, though he had no intention of drinking it. He looked at Jordan, who was watching the door where Daisy and Gatsby had disappeared. He suddenly remembered that it was his thirtieth birthday. The thought struck him like a blow. He had never felt it before, but now it seemed to settle in his bones like a weight.

As they drove back across the bridge, Tom was in high spirits, talking about the stock market and the latest political scandal. Nick sat in silence, watching the lights of the city blur into the distance. Jordan sat beside him, her hand resting lightly on his knee, and for a moment he forgot about the number. He forgot about the future, the loneliness, the slow decline that came with turning thirty. He only felt the cool night air and the soft pressure of Jordan’s fingers.

But as they neared Long Island, the illusion faded. He looked out at the dark water and the distant lights of the city, and he felt the weight of the years settle on him again. It was as if they were driving toward death through the cooling twilight.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Please, Tom! I can’t stand this any more.”

Daisy’s voice cracked with emotion, and for a moment, the room seemed to hold its breath. Tom, seated in his usual chair, barely looked up from the newspaper he was reading. His indifference was a wall, impenetrable and cruel. “What do you want me to do, Daisy?” he asked, his tone dismissive, as if her suffering were a minor inconvenience rather than a breaking point.

“I want you to listen to me,” she said, her voice trembling. “I want you to care about what I feel. I want you to stop pretending that everything is fine when it’s not.”

Tom finally looked at her, his eyes cold and unyielding. “You’re being dramatic, Daisy. You always are. You think you’re the only one who suffers in this marriage?”

Daisy’s hands clenched into fists at her sides. “I’m not the one who brought another woman into our home. I’m not the one who lies to my face and calls it love.”

Tom’s jaw tightened. “That’s not fair. You know I never loved her the way I love you.”

Daisy laughed bitterly. “Love? You don’t know the meaning of the word. You take what you want and leave the rest of us to pick up the pieces.”

Tom stood up, towering over her. “You’re not making sense, Daisy. You’re upset, and I’m tired of it. You need to calm down.”

But Daisy was no longer listening. She was too far gone, too broken to be soothed by his empty words. “I can’t do this anymore, Tom. I can’t live like this.”

Tom’s face darkened with anger. “Then leave. Go back to your precious Gatsby. I don’t care.”

Daisy’s eyes filled with tears, but she didn’t move. “I don’t want to be with Gatsby. I just want to be with someone who loves me.”

Tom turned away, unwilling to face the truth in her words. The silence that followed was heavy with unspoken pain, and in that moment, the illusion of their marriage shattered completely.

events.title: Michaelis's Testimony: Events Leading to Myrtle's Death
detailed_summary: Michaelis, owner of a nearby coffee shop, is identified as the primary witness.
He found Wilson sick and distressed in his office around 5 PM.
Wilson refused to rest, mentioning he had locked Myrtle upstairs.
Wilson revealed his plan to move away with Myrtle the day after tomorrow, surprising Michaelis with his newfound resolve.
Wilson became suspicious of Michaelis, questioning his whereabouts.
Michaelis left when customers arrived, intending to return later but forgot.
Around 7 PM, Michaelis heard Myrtle shouting angrily downstairs in the garage, accusing Wilson of cowardice.
Moments later, Myrtle rushed out into the road, waving her arms.
Before Michaelis could react, she was struck by a car.
The car, described later by newspapers as the 'death car,' did not stop and disappeared.
Michaelis initially told police the car was light green.
The driver of another car, heading towards New York, stopped and rushed back with Michaelis to Myrtle.
They found Myrtle obviously dead, her chest mutilated and mouth open.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The mouth was wide open and ripped a little at the corners, as though she had choked a little in giving up the tremendous vitality she had stored so long.

events.text_segment:
The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest. He had slept through the heat until after five, when he strolled over to the garage, and found George Wilson sick in his office—really sick, pale as his own pale hair and shaking all over. Michaelis advised him to go to bed, but Wilson refused, saying that he’d miss a lot of business if he did. While his neighbour was trying to persuade him a violent racket broke out overhead.
“I’ve got my wife locked in up there,” explained Wilson calmly. “She’s going to stay there till the day after tomorrow, and then we’re going to move away.”
Michaelis was astonished; they had been neighbours for four years, and Wilson had never seemed faintly capable of such a statement. Generally he was one of these worn-out men: when he wasn’t working, he sat on a chair in the doorway and stared at the people and the cars that passed along the road. When anyone spoke to him he invariably laughed in an agreeable, colourless way. He was his wife’s man and not his own.
So naturally Michaelis tried to find out what had happened, but Wilson wouldn’t say a word—instead he began to throw curious, suspicious glances at his visitor and ask him what he’d been doing at certain times on certain days. Just as the latter was getting uneasy, some workmen came past the door bound for his restaurant, and Michaelis took the opportunity to get away, intending to come back later. But he didn’t. He supposed he forgot to, that’s all. When he came outside again, a little after seven, he was reminded of the conversation because he heard Mrs. Wilson’s voice, loud and scolding, downstairs in the garage.
“Beat me!” he heard her cry. “Throw me down and beat me, you dirty little coward!”
A moment later she rushed out into the dusk, waving her hands and shouting—before he could move from his door the business was over.
The “death car” as the newspapers called it, didn’t stop; it came out of the gathering darkness, wavered tragically for a moment, and then disappeared around the next bend. Mavro Michaelis wasn’t even sure of its colour—he told the first policeman that it was light green. The other car, the one going toward New York, came to rest a hundred yards beyond, and its driver hurried back to where Myrtle Wilson, her life violently extinguished, knelt in the road and mingled her thick dark blood with the dust.
Michaelis and this man reached her first, but when they had torn open her shirtwaist, still damp with perspiration, they saw that her left breast was swinging loose like a flap, and there was no need to listen for the heart beneath. The mouth was wide open and ripped a little at the corners, as though she had choked a little in giving up the tremendous vitality she had stored so long.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest. He was a simple, well-meaning young man, who had never been in a court of law before, and he blinked at the coroner as if he had never heard of death. He told the story of that afternoon with the diffidence of a man who had never before been asked to give an account of himself. He had found Wilson sick and distressed in his office about five o’clock. He had tried to get him to rest, but Wilson had refused, saying he had locked Myrtle upstairs. He had a new idea, he said, a new idea that would take them both away from this place the day after tomorrow. Michaelis, who had never known Wilson to be so resolute, was surprised. But Wilson, who had been a passive, almost effeminate man, now showed a strange and terrible energy. He began to question Michaelis, suspicious of his movements, and finally, when customers came in, Michaelis left, intending to return later. But he forgot. It was about seven o’clock when he heard Myrtle’s voice, shrill and angry, coming from the garage. He ran out and saw her standing in the road, her arms waving, her face contorted with rage. Before he could reach her, she was struck by a car. The car, as the newspapers afterwards described it, was the 'death car,' and it did not stop. It disappeared into the night. Michaelis, dazed and trembling, gave the police a description of the car as light green. Later, another car, going toward New York, stopped and the driver, a man with a red mustache, rushed back with Michaelis to the scene. They found Myrtle dead, her chest mangled and her mouth open in a final, silent scream.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The young Greek, Michaelis, who ran the coffee joint beside the ash-heaps was the principal witness at the inquest. He was a quiet, unassuming man, with a nervous manner and a habit of speaking in a low voice, as if afraid of being overheard. He had lived in the area for many years, and his small coffee shop was a place where the few residents of the desolate stretch of land near the valley of ashes would gather to pass the time. Michaelis was not a man of great eloquence, but his testimony was clear and direct, and it painted a picture of the tragic events that had unfolded on that fateful night.

Michaelis had been in his shop when he heard the screech of tires and the muffled thud of something—or someone—being struck. He had rushed outside and seen a car speeding away in the distance, leaving behind a trail of dust and the broken body of Myrtle Wilson, the wife of his employer, George Wilson. He had gone to her aid, but she was already dead. Her face was twisted in a final expression of terror, and her blood stained the ground where she lay.

Michaelis had known Myrtle for years. She had often come into the coffee shop, always with a cigarette in her hand and a look of restless dissatisfaction in her eyes. She had been a woman of contradictions—beautiful, yet unfulfilled; lively, yet trapped in a loveless marriage. Michaelis had never been close to her, but he had felt a certain sympathy for her plight. He had seen the way she looked at other men, the way she longed for something more than the life she had with George.

At the inquest, Michaelis was asked if he had seen anything of the driver of the car. He shook his head. The night had been dark, and the car had vanished into the distance before he could get a good look at it. But he did remember seeing a man with a yellow smile, a man who had been with Myrtle just before the accident. It was Tom Buchanan, the husband of Daisy, the woman Gatsby had loved. Michaelis did not know the names of the people involved, but he had seen the way they had argued, the way Myrtle had laughed and then cried, and the way the man with the yellow smile had left her standing there, alone.

Michaelis was not a man of great insight, but he understood that something had gone terribly wrong. He had seen the end of a story that had been building for a long time, and he had been left to pick up the pieces. He did not know what would happen to Gatsby, or to Tom, or to the others who had played a part in the tragedy. He only knew that the world he had known had changed, and that the valley of ashes would remain, as it always had, a place of broken dreams and forgotten lives.

events.title: Discovery of Myrtle's Body and Tom's Deflection
detailed_summary: Tom, Nick, and Jordan see the crowd and cars at Wilson's garage from a distance.
Tom initially remarks cynically that the wreck might bring Wilson some business.
The somber faces of the crowd prompt Tom to stop the car.
They hear Wilson's continuous, agonizing cries of 'Oh, my God!' from inside.
Tom pushes through the crowd into the garage.
Nick and Jordan are pushed inside shortly after.
They see Myrtle's body wrapped in blankets on a workbench.
Tom stands over the body, motionless, while a policeman takes notes.
Wilson is seen swaying in his office doorway, oblivious and crying out repeatedly.
Tom abruptly confronts the policeman, demanding to know what happened.
The policeman explains Myrtle was hit by a car that didn't stop.
Michaelis clarifies that Myrtle ran out into the road and was hit by a car coming from New York.
A bystander describes the car as a big, new, yellow car, driving very fast.
Hearing this, Wilson cries out that he knows what kind of car it was.
Tom quickly goes to Wilson, grips his arms, and tells him firmly that he just arrived from New York and the yellow car he drove earlier wasn't his.
The policeman questions Tom about his own car, which Tom identifies as the blue coupé.
Nick confirms they came straight from New York.
Tom carries the distraught Wilson into his office and asks others to sit with him.
Tom tells Nick and Jordan they should leave, avoiding looking at Myrtle's body.
They push through the crowd, passing a doctor arriving too late.
Tom drives away slowly at first, then speeds up.
Tom begins to sob, calling the driver who hit Myrtle a 'God damned coward'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We saw the three or four automobiles and the crowd when we were still some distance away.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The God damned coward!” he whimpered.

events.text_segment:
We saw the three or four automobiles and the crowd when we were still some distance away.
“Wreck!” said Tom. “That’s good. Wilson’ll have a little business at last.”
He slowed down, but still without any intention of stopping, until, as we came nearer, the hushed, intent faces of the people at the garage door made him automatically put on the brakes.
“We’ll take a look,” he said doubtfully, “just a look.”
I became aware now of a hollow, wailing sound which issued incessantly from the garage, a sound which as we got out of the coupé and walked toward the door resolved itself into the words “Oh, my God!” uttered over and over in a gasping moan.
“There’s some bad trouble here,” said Tom excitedly.
He reached up on tiptoes and peered over a circle of heads into the garage, which was lit only by a yellow light in a swinging metal basket overhead. Then he made a harsh sound in his throat, and with a violent thrusting movement of his powerful arms pushed his way through.
The circle closed up again with a running murmur of expostulation; it was a minute before I could see anything at all. Then new arrivals deranged the line, and Jordan and I were pushed suddenly inside.
Myrtle Wilson’s body, wrapped in a blanket, and then in another blanket, as though she suffered from a chill in the hot night, lay on a worktable by the wall, and Tom, with his back to us, was bending over it, motionless. Next to him stood a motorcycle policeman taking down names with much sweat and correction in a little book. At first I couldn’t find the source of the high, groaning words that echoed clamorously through the bare garage—then I saw Wilson standing on the raised threshold of his office, swaying back and forth and holding to the doorposts with both hands. Some man was talking to him in a low voice and attempting, from time to time, to lay a hand on his shoulder, but Wilson neither heard nor saw. His eyes would drop slowly from the swinging light to the laden table by the wall, and then jerk back to the light again, and he gave out incessantly his high, horrible call:
“Oh, my Ga-od! Oh, my Ga-od! Oh, Ga-od! Oh, my Ga-od!”
Presently Tom lifted his head with a jerk and, after staring around the garage with glazed eyes, addressed a mumbled incoherent remark to the policeman.
“M-a-v—” the policeman was saying, “—o—”
“No, r—” corrected the man, “M-a-v-r-o—”
“Listen to me!” muttered Tom fiercely.
“r—” said the policeman, “o—”
“g—”
“g—” He looked up as Tom’s broad hand fell sharply on his shoulder. “What you want, fella?”
“What happened?—that’s what I want to know.”
“Auto hit her. Ins’antly killed.”
“Instantly killed,” repeated Tom, staring.
“She ran out ina road. Son-of-a-bitch didn’t even stopus car.”
“There was two cars,” said Michaelis, “one comin’, one goin’, see?”
“Going where?” asked the policeman keenly.
“One goin’ each way. Well, she”—his hand rose toward the blankets but stopped halfway and fell to his side—“she ran out there an’ the one comin’ from N’York knock right into her, goin’ thirty or forty miles an hour.”
“What’s the name of this place here?” demanded the officer.
“Hasn’t got any name.”
A pale well-dressed negro stepped near.
“It was a yellow car,” he said, “big yellow car. New.”
“See the accident?” asked the policeman.
“No, but the car passed me down the road, going faster’n forty. Going fifty, sixty.”
“Come here and let’s have your name. Look out now. I want to get his name.”
Some words of this conversation must have reached Wilson, swaying in the office door, for suddenly a new theme found voice among his grasping cries:
“You don’t have to tell me what kind of car it was! I know what kind of car it was!”
Watching Tom, I saw the wad of muscle back of his shoulder tighten under his coat. He walked quickly over to Wilson and, standing in front of him, seized him firmly by the upper arms.
“You’ve got to pull yourself together,” he said with soothing gruffness.
Wilson’s eyes fell upon Tom; he started up on his tiptoes and then would have collapsed to his knees had not Tom held him upright.
“Listen,” said Tom, shaking him a little. “I just got here a minute ago, from New York. I was bringing you that coupé we’ve been talking about. That yellow car I was driving this afternoon wasn’t mine—do you hear? I haven’t seen it all afternoon.”
Only the negro and I were near enough to hear what he said, but the policeman caught something in the tone and looked over with truculent eyes.
“What’s all that?” he demanded.
“I’m a friend of his.” Tom turned his head but kept his hands firm on Wilson’s body. “He says he knows the car that did it… It was a yellow car.”
Some dim impulse moved the policeman to look suspiciously at Tom.
“And what colour’s your car?”
“It’s a blue car, a coupé.”
“We’ve come straight from New York,” I said.
Someone who had been driving a little behind us confirmed this, and the policeman turned away.
“Now, if you’ll let me have that name again correct—”
Picking up Wilson like a doll, Tom carried him into the office, set him down in a chair, and came back.
“If somebody’ll come here and sit with him,” he snapped authoritatively. He watched while the two men standing closest glanced at each other and went unwillingly into the room. Then Tom shut the door on them and came down the single step, his eyes avoiding the table. As he passed close to me he whispered: “Let’s get out.”
Self-consciously, with his authoritative arms breaking the way, we pushed through the still gathering crowd, passing a hurried doctor, case in hand, who had been sent for in wild hope half an hour ago.
Tom drove slowly until we were beyond the bend—then his foot came down hard, and the coupé raced along through the night. In a little while I heard a low husky sob, and saw that the tears were overflowing down his face.
“The God damned coward!” he whimpered.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
We saw the three or four automobiles and the crowd when we were still some distance away. They had already drawn a cordon around the garage, and the yellow car that had been parked there was gone. Tom's voice, which had been cynical and indifferent, suddenly took on a note of grim amusement. 'Maybe this will bring him some business,' he said. But as we drew closer and saw the somber, hushed faces of the people gathered, he stopped the car abruptly. 'I don't want to see it,' he muttered, but he got out anyway, and we followed.

The cries from inside were already reaching us—'Oh, my God! Oh, my God!'—a continuous, broken wail that seemed to come from the very heart of the place. Tom pushed through the crowd, and we followed, stepping over the feet of the onlookers. Inside, the garage was dim and smelled of oil and death. Myrtle's body was on a workbench, wrapped in a sheet, and a policeman was taking notes beside it. Wilson was in the doorway of his office, swaying slightly, his face pale and uncomprehending, still crying out, 'Oh, my God! Oh, my God!'

Tom stood over the body, motionless, his face set in a mask of cold determination. 'What happened?' he demanded of the policeman. The officer hesitated, then said, 'She was hit by a car that didn't stop.' Michaelis, the man who had found her, added, 'She ran out into the road. The car came from New York.'

A bystander, a man with a red face and a loud voice, said, 'It was a big, new, yellow car. It was going like hell.' Wilson, hearing this, turned suddenly and cried out, 'I know what kind of car it was! I know who it was!' Tom moved quickly to him, gripping his arms. 'You just came from New York,' he said, his voice low and firm. 'The yellow car you drove wasn't yours.'

The policeman asked Tom about his own car, and Tom said it was a blue coupé. I confirmed that we had come straight from New York. Tom then led Wilson into his office and asked the others to sit with him. 'We should go,' he said to me and Jordan, and we pushed our way back through the crowd, past the doctor who had just arrived too late.

As we drove away, Tom was silent for a long time. Then, suddenly, he began to sob, his voice breaking. 'God damned coward,' he said, over and over, as if trying to exorcise the name from his mind.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We saw the three or four automobiles and the crowd when we were still some distance away. They had already arrived at the scene, and the excitement was palpable. The air was thick with anticipation and the murmurs of the onlookers. As we drew closer, the details became clearer. The cars were parked haphazardly, their hoods up and engines still warm. A few men in dark suits stood near the vehicles, their expressions grim and their postures tense. The crowd had gathered around them, a mix of curious neighbors, reporters, and gawkers, all eager to catch a glimpse of what had transpired.

The scene was one of controlled chaos. A police officer in a crisp uniform was directing traffic, his whistle sharp and commanding. A few uniformed men were already taking notes, their notepads and pencils at the ready. The sun was beginning to set, casting long shadows across the pavement and giving the scene a surreal, almost dreamlike quality. The colors of the evening were muted, the sky a deepening shade of orange and purple, and the light seemed to filter through the smoke and dust that hung in the air.

As we approached, I could see the body lying on the ground, a figure wrapped in a white sheet. The sight was jarring, and I felt a wave of nausea rise in my throat. The people around me murmured in hushed tones, their voices tinged with a mix of horror and morbid curiosity. I could see the faces of the onlookers, some pale and shaken, others with a detached, almost clinical interest. The air was thick with the scent of gasoline and the acrid smoke from the burning car, and I could feel the heat radiating from the wreckage.

A man in a dark overcoat stepped forward, his face partially obscured by the brim of his hat. He was speaking to the police, his voice low and urgent. I could not make out the words, but the tone was unmistakable. He was trying to convey something important, something that had just happened. I could see the tension in his shoulders, the way his hands moved as he spoke, and I could feel the weight of the moment pressing down on everyone present.

The crowd began to shift, a slow and deliberate movement as people made way for the ambulance that had just arrived. The siren wailed faintly in the distance, a sound that seemed to cut through the stillness of the evening. The paramedics moved quickly, their movements efficient and practiced. They worked with a calmness that was almost unsettling, as if they were used to this kind of scene. I could see the body being lifted onto a stretcher, the white sheet slipping slightly to reveal a glimpse of the face beneath.

I turned away, unable to bear the sight. The weight of the moment was too much to bear, and I felt a wave of dizziness wash over me. I leaned against the hood of a nearby car, my hands trembling slightly. The people around me continued to murmur, their voices a low and constant hum. I could hear snippets of conversation, fragments of speculation and rumor. Some said it was an accident, others whispered of something more sinister. The truth, I realized, was still unknown, and perhaps it always would be.

The police officer who had been directing traffic now approached us, his expression unreadable. He was a tall man with a broad build, his face weathered and lined with experience. He spoke to us in a calm, measured tone, asking for our names and where we had been when the incident occurred. I could see the strain in his eyes, the way he was trying to maintain control of the situation. He was a man who had seen too much, who had learned to keep his emotions in check, even in the face of tragedy.

As we answered his questions, I could feel the weight of the moment pressing down on me. The events of the evening had taken on a surreal quality, as if I were watching a movie rather than experiencing it firsthand. The people around me, the cars, the police, the body on the ground—it all seemed to exist in a world apart from my own. I could not shake the feeling that I was an outsider, a spectator to something that was not meant for me to witness.

The sun had now set completely, and the sky was a deep, inky black. The streetlights flickered on, casting a pale, artificial glow over the scene. The crowd began to thin, the onlookers gradually dispersing as the night deepened. The police continued their work, their movements precise and methodical. The paramedics had already left, the body taken away in the ambulance. The only thing left was the wreckage of the car, a silent and ominous reminder of what had happened.

I stood there for a moment longer, watching as the last of the crowd disappeared into the night. The air was cool now, the heat of the day giving way to the chill of the evening. I could hear the distant sound of a car engine, the soft hum of the city continuing its endless rhythm. I turned and walked away, my steps slow and deliberate. The events of the evening would stay with me, a memory that would linger in the back of my mind, a reminder of the fragility of life and the unpredictability of fate.

events.title: Gatsby's Watch and Tom and Daisy's Reconciliation
detailed_summary: They arrive back at the Buchanans' house.
Tom notes Daisy is home, seeing lights on.
Tom becomes serious and decisive, telling Nick he should have dropped him off and suggesting Nick and Jordan get supper while waiting for a taxi.
Nick declines to go inside, feeling sick and wanting distance from everyone, including Jordan.
Jordan seems to understand Nick's withdrawal and goes inside.
Nick waits outside, hearing the butler call for a taxi.
Walking down the drive, Nick encounters Gatsby hiding in the bushes.
Gatsby asks if Nick saw the 'trouble' on the road and confirms hearing Myrtle was killed.
Gatsby claims Daisy 'stood it pretty well,' focusing solely on her reaction.
He recounts taking a side road back and hiding the car, hoping they weren't seen.
Nick, disliking Gatsby intensely at this moment, doesn't correct him.
Gatsby asks who the woman was.
Gatsby starts to explain the accident, saying he 'tried to swing the wheel,' leading Nick to guess the truth.
Gatsby confirms Daisy was driving but insists he will take the blame.
He explains Daisy was nervous and wanted to drive, and the woman (Myrtle) rushed out unexpectedly as if recognizing them.
Gatsby says Daisy swerved, lost her nerve, swerved back, and he felt the impact just as he grabbed the wheel.
He says Daisy couldn't stop, so he pulled the emergency brake and drove on after she collapsed into his lap.
Gatsby declares he will wait outside all night to ensure Tom doesn't harm Daisy.
Nick, concerned Tom might discover Daisy drove, offers to check the house.
Nick walks back and peers through the pantry window.
He sees Tom and Daisy sitting intimately at the kitchen table over untouched food and ale.
Tom is talking earnestly, his hand covering hers; Daisy nods in agreement occasionally.
Nick observes they appear not happy, yet not unhappy, sharing an air of 'natural intimacy' and seemingly 'conspiring together'.
Nick returns to Gatsby, assures him all is quiet, and advises him to go home.
Gatsby refuses, determined to continue his vigil.
Nick leaves Gatsby standing alone in the moonlight, 'watching over nothing'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So I walked away and left him standing there in the moonlight—watching over nothing.

events.text_segment:
The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees. Tom stopped beside the porch and looked up at the second floor, where two windows bloomed with light among the vines.
“Daisy’s home,” he said. As we got out of the car he glanced at me and frowned slightly.
“I ought to have dropped you in West Egg, Nick. There’s nothing we can do tonight.”
A change had come over him, and he spoke gravely, and with decision. As we walked across the moonlight gravel to the porch he disposed of the situation in a few brisk phrases.
“I’ll telephone for a taxi to take you home, and while you’re waiting you and Jordan better go in the kitchen and have them get you some supper—if you want any.” He opened the door. “Come in.”
“No, thanks. But I’d be glad if you’d order me the taxi. I’ll wait outside.”
Jordan put her hand on my arm.
“Won’t you come in, Nick?”
“No, thanks.”
I was feeling a little sick and I wanted to be alone. But Jordan lingered for a moment more.
“It’s only half-past nine,” she said.
I’d be damned if I’d go in; I’d had enough of all of them for one day, and suddenly that included Jordan too. She must have seen something of this in my expression, for she turned abruptly away and ran up the porch steps into the house. I sat down for a few minutes with my head in my hands, until I heard the phone taken up inside and the butler’s voice calling a taxi. Then I walked slowly down the drive away from the house, intending to wait by the gate.
I hadn’t gone twenty yards when I heard my name and Gatsby stepped from between two bushes into the path. I must have felt pretty weird by that time, because I could think of nothing except the luminosity of his pink suit under the moon.
“What are you doing?” I inquired.
“Just standing here, old sport.”
Somehow, that seemed a despicable occupation. For all I knew he was going to rob the house in a moment; I wouldn’t have been surprised to see sinister faces, the faces of “Wolfshiem’s people,” behind him in the dark shrubbery.
“Did you see any trouble on the road?” he asked after a minute.
“Yes.”
He hesitated.
“Was she killed?”
“Yes.”
“I thought so; I told Daisy I thought so. It’s better that the shock should all come at once. She stood it pretty well.”
He spoke as if Daisy’s reaction was the only thing that mattered.
“I got to West Egg by a side road,” he went on, “and left the car in my garage. I don’t think anybody saw us, but of course I can’t be sure.”
I disliked him so much by this time that I didn’t find it necessary to tell him he was wrong.
“Who was the woman?” he inquired.
“Her name was Wilson. Her husband owns the garage. How the devil did it happen?”
“Well, I tried to swing the wheel—” He broke off, and suddenly I guessed at the truth.
“Was Daisy driving?”
“Yes,” he said after a moment, “but of course I’ll say I was. You see, when we left New York she was very nervous and she thought it would steady her to drive—and this woman rushed out at us just as we were passing a car coming the other way. It all happened in a minute, but it seemed to me that she wanted to speak to us, thought we were somebody she knew. Well, first Daisy turned away from the woman toward the other car, and then she lost her nerve and turned back. The second my hand reached the wheel I felt the shock—it must have killed her instantly.”
“It ripped her open—”
“Don’t tell me, old sport.” He winced. “Anyhow—Daisy stepped on it. I tried to make her stop, but she couldn’t, so I pulled on the emergency brake. Then she fell over into my lap and I drove on.
“She’ll be all right tomorrow,” he said presently. “I’m just going to wait here and see if he tries to bother her about that unpleasantness this afternoon. She’s locked herself into her room, and if he tries any brutality she’s going to turn the light out and on again.”
“He won’t touch her,” I said. “He’s not thinking about her.”
“I don’t trust him, old sport.”
“How long are you going to wait?”
“All night, if necessary. Anyhow, till they all go to bed.”
A new point of view occurred to me. Suppose Tom found out that Daisy had been driving. He might think he saw a connection in it—he might think anything. I looked at the house; there were two or three bright windows downstairs and the pink glow from Daisy’s room on the ground floor.
“You wait here,” I said. “I’ll see if there’s any sign of a commotion.”
I walked back along the border of the lawn, traversed the gravel softly, and tiptoed up the veranda steps. The drawing-room curtains were open, and I saw that the room was empty. Crossing the porch where we had dined that June night three months before, I came to a small rectangle of light which I guessed was the pantry window. The blind was drawn, but I found a rift at the sill.
Daisy and Tom were sitting opposite each other at the kitchen table, with a plate of cold fried chicken between them, and two bottles of ale. He was talking intently across the table at her, and in his earnestness his hand had fallen upon and covered her own. Once in a while she looked up at him and nodded in agreement.
They weren’t happy, and neither of them had touched the chicken or the ale—and yet they weren’t unhappy either. There was an unmistakable air of natural intimacy about the picture, and anybody would have said that they were conspiring together.
As I tiptoed from the porch I heard my taxi feeling its way along the dark road toward the house. Gatsby was waiting where I had left him in the drive.
“Is it all quiet up there?” he asked anxiously.
“Yes, it’s all quiet.” I hesitated. “You’d better come home and get some sleep.”
He shook his head.
“I want to wait here till Daisy goes to bed. Good night, old sport.”
He put his hands in his coat pockets and turned back eagerly to his scrutiny of the house, as though my presence marred the sacredness of the vigil. So I walked away and left him standing there in the moonlight—watching over nothing.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees. We stopped at the gate, and I saw the lights on in the long yellow hall and the living room beyond. Tom noted it with a kind of grim satisfaction. “She’s home,” he said. “I suppose she’s home.” He became serious and decisive. “You should have dropped me at the station, Nick,” he said. “You and Jordan go in and get something to eat while you wait for a taxi.” I declined to go in. I felt sick and I wanted to be alone. Jordan seemed to understand. She went in, and I waited outside, hearing the butler call for a taxi. I walked down the drive, past the white gate, and found Gatsby crouched in the bushes like a man hiding from the police. “Did you see the trouble on the road?” he asked. “Was it Myrtle?” I nodded. “Daisy stood it pretty well,” he said. “I only care about Daisy.” He told me how he had taken a side road back and hidden the car, hoping no one had seen them. I disliked him, I loathed him, I thought he was a terrible man. “Who was the woman?” Gatsby asked. He began to explain the accident. “I tried to swing the wheel,” he said, and I guessed the truth. “Daisy was driving,” he confirmed. “She was nervous, and she wanted to drive. The woman—she rushed out as if she knew us. Daisy swerved, lost her nerve, swerved back—and I felt the impact just as I grabbed the wheel. She collapsed into my lap. I pulled the emergency brake and drove on.” He said Daisy couldn’t stop, so he had to take the blame. “I’ll wait outside all night,” he said. “I won’t let Tom hurt her.” I was afraid Tom might find out Daisy had been driving. I offered to check the house. I walked back and peered through the pantry window. Tom and Daisy were sitting at the kitchen table, untouched food and ale between them. Tom was talking earnestly, his hand over hers. Daisy nodded occasionally. They were not happy, but they were not unhappy. They had an air of natural intimacy, as if they were conspiring together. I returned to Gatsby and told him all was quiet. He refused to go home. I left him standing alone in the moonlight, watching over nothing.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The Buchanans’ house floated suddenly toward us through the dark rustling trees. It was a cheerful red-and-white Georgian Colonial mansion, overlooking the bay, with a tower on one side, and a marble swimming pool and a large garden in front. The lights were on in the windows, and the whole house seemed to be glowing with a warm, inviting light, as if it were a beacon in the night. It was a house that seemed to belong to a different world, a world of wealth and privilege, far removed from the gray, industrial landscape of West Egg where I lived. I had never been inside, but I had seen it from a distance many times, and it always seemed to me to be a symbol of everything that was beautiful and unattainable. The Buchanans were one of the old-money families of East Egg, and they were known for their lavish parties and their effortless charm. Tom Buchanan was a former football player, tall and broad-shouldered, with a voice that could command a room. He was the kind of man who could make people feel small just by looking at them. His wife, Daisy, was a delicate, fragile-looking woman with a voice full of money, as Nick would later describe it. She was the kind of woman who could make a man feel like he was the only one in the world who mattered to her. I had met them once before, at a party in New York, and I had been struck by their effortless grace and their complete confidence in their own superiority. They were the kind of people who never had to worry about anything, who could do whatever they wanted and say whatever they wanted, and who would never be held accountable for their actions. As we approached the house, I could see that the party was in full swing. There were people laughing and dancing on the lawn, and the sound of music and conversation drifted out into the night. The house was alive with color and light, and it seemed to be a world unto itself, a world where time stood still and nothing mattered except the present moment. I felt a pang of envy as I looked at the house, and I wondered what it would be like to live in a place like that, to be part of a world where everything was perfect and nothing was ever questioned. But I also felt a sense of unease, as if I were about to step into a world that was not meant for me, a world that would not welcome me with open arms. I had heard stories about the Buchanans, about the way they treated their servants and the way they looked down on people like me, who had come from nothing and had to work for everything they had. I had also heard about the way they treated each other, about the way Tom had a mistress and about the way Daisy had once loved someone else. I had heard about the way they lived their lives, as if they were above the rules that governed the rest of the world. As we pulled up to the house, I saw that there was a long line of cars waiting to be let in, and I realized that this was going to be one of those parties that would go on for hours, that would be filled with people who had nothing better to do than to drink and dance and flirt and forget. I saw Tom and Daisy standing on the porch, looking out at the crowd of guests, and I felt a strange sense of anticipation. I had no idea what to expect, but I knew that whatever was about to happen would be unforgettable. I stepped out of the car and felt the cool night air on my face, and I looked up at the house one more time. It was beautiful, but it was also a little bit scary, like a fairy tale castle that had been built on a dark and dangerous foundation. I had no idea what was waiting for me inside, but I knew that I was about to step into a world that was not my own, a world that would change me in ways I could not yet imagine.

events.title: Nick's Anxious Vigil and Gatsby's Despair
detailed_summary: Nick spends a sleepless night disturbed by a foghorn and troubling thoughts, feeling an urgent need to warn Gatsby.
He goes to Gatsby's house at dawn, finding the door open and Gatsby inside, looking exhausted and dejected.
Gatsby reports that Daisy came to the window briefly during the night but then turned off the light, offering no resolution.
Nick observes the immense, dusty, and unused state of Gatsby's mansion as they search for cigarettes, highlighting its emptiness.
They sit smoking by the open windows.
Nick advises Gatsby to leave town immediately, suggesting Atlantic City or Montreal, fearing Gatsby's car will be traced back to the accident.
Gatsby refuses, stating he cannot leave until he knows Daisy's decision, clinging to a final hope.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.

events.text_segment:
I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. Toward dawn I heard a taxi go up Gatsby’s drive, and immediately I jumped out of bed and began to dress—I felt that I had something to tell him, something to warn him about, and morning would be too late.
Crossing his lawn, I saw that his front door was still open and he was leaning against a table in the hall, heavy with dejection or sleep.
“Nothing happened,” he said wanly. “I waited, and about four o’clock she came to the window and stood there for a minute and then turned out the light.”
His house had never seemed so enormous to me as it did that night when we hunted through the great rooms for cigarettes. We pushed aside curtains that were like pavilions, and felt over innumerable feet of dark wall for electric light switches—once I tumbled with a sort of splash upon the keys of a ghostly piano. There was an inexplicable amount of dust everywhere, and the rooms were musty, as though they hadn’t been aired for many days. I found the humidor on an unfamiliar table, with two stale, dry cigarettes inside. Throwing open the French windows of the drawing-room, we sat smoking out into the darkness.
“You ought to go away,” I said. “It’s pretty certain they’ll trace your car.”
“Go away now, old sport?”
“Go to Atlantic City for a week, or up to Montreal.”
He wouldn’t consider it. He couldn’t possibly leave Daisy until he knew what she was going to do. He was clutching at some last hope and I couldn’t bear to shake him free.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: I couldn’t sleep all night; a foghorn was groaning incessantly on the Sound, and I tossed half-sick between grotesque reality and savage, frightening dreams. At dawn I was still awake, and I thought of Gatsby’s fantastic capacity for hope; and he had taken the past so literally that he believed he could repeat it. I went to Gatsby’s house at nine o’clock in the morning and found the door open. A faint light filtered through the windows, and the house was still and empty. I found him in the library, looking at the books on the shelves as if he had never seen them before. He turned when I came in, and his face was pale and drawn. “Daisy came to the window last night,” he said. “She stood there for a minute, and then she turned out the light and went away.” I saw at once that he was waiting for something that would never come. We went out into the hall and searched for cigarettes, and I noticed how dusty and unused the house was. The furniture was covered with sheets, and the air was thick with the smell of old paper and mildew. We sat down by the open windows and smoked in silence. “You ought to go away, Gatsby,” I said at last. “You ought to go to Atlantic City or Montreal or somewhere. This place is cursed. They’ll trace the car back to you, and then it’ll be all over.” He shook his head. “I can’t go until I know,” he said. “I can’t leave until I know what she’s decided.” He looked out over the empty lawn and the gray morning, and I saw the last flicker of hope in his eyes. It was a hope that had no place in the world we lived in, but he clung to it with all the desperation of a man who had nothing left.

events.text_segment:
It was this night that he told me the strange story of his youth with Dan Cody—told it to me because “Jay Gatsby” had broken up like glass against Tom’s hard malice, and the long secret extravaganza was played out. I think that he would have acknowledged anything now, without reserve, but he wanted to talk about Daisy.
She was the first “nice” girl he had ever known. In various unrevealed capacities he had come in contact with such people, but always with indiscernible barbed wire between. He found her excitingly desirable. He went to her house, at first with other officers from Camp Taylor, then alone. It amazed him—he had never been in such a beautiful house before. But what gave it an air of breathless intensity, was that Daisy lived there—it was as casual a thing to her as his tent out at camp was to him. There was a ripe mystery about it, a hint of bedrooms upstairs more beautiful and cool than other bedrooms, of gay and radiant activities taking place through its corridors, and of romances that were not musty and laid away already in lavender but fresh and breathing and redolent of this year’s shining motorcars and of dances whose flowers were scarcely withered. It excited him, too, that many men had already loved Daisy—it increased her value in his eyes. He felt their presence all about the house, pervading the air with the shades and echoes of still vibrant emotions.
But he knew that he was in Daisy’s house by a colossal accident. However glorious might be his future as Jay Gatsby, he was at present a penniless young man without a past, and at any moment the invisible cloak of his uniform might slip from his shoulders. So he made the most of his time. He took what he could get, ravenously and unscrupulously—eventually he took Daisy one still October night, took her because he had no real right to touch her hand.
He might have despised himself, for he had certainly taken her under false pretences. I don’t mean that he had traded on his phantom millions, but he had deliberately given Daisy a sense of security; he let her believe that he was a person from much the same strata as herself—that he was fully able to take care of her. As a matter of fact, he had no such facilities—he had no comfortable family standing behind him, and he was liable at the whim of an impersonal government to be blown anywhere about the world.
But he didn’t despise himself and it didn’t turn out as he had imagined. He had intended, probably, to take what he could and go—but now he found that he had committed himself to the following of a grail. He knew that Daisy was extraordinary, but he didn’t realize just how extraordinary a “nice” girl could be. She vanished into her rich house, into her rich, full life, leaving Gatsby—nothing. He felt married to her, that was all.
When they met again, two days later, it was Gatsby who was breathless, who was, somehow, betrayed. Her porch was bright with the bought luxury of star-shine; the wicker of the settee squeaked fashionably as she turned toward him and he kissed her curious and lovely mouth. She had caught a cold, and it made her voice huskier and more charming than ever, and Gatsby was overwhelmingly aware of the youth and mystery that wealth imprisons and preserves, of the freshness of many clothes, and of Daisy, gleaming like silver, safe and proud above the hot struggles of the poor.
“I can’t describe to you how surprised I was to find out I loved her, old sport. I even hoped for a while that she’d throw me over, but she didn’t, because she was in love with me too. She thought I knew a lot because I knew different things from her… Well, there I was, way off my ambitions, getting deeper in love every minute, and all of a sudden I didn’t care. What was the use of doing great things if I could have a better time telling her what I was going to do?”
On the last afternoon before he went abroad, he sat with Daisy in his arms for a long, silent time. It was a cold fall day, with fire in the room and her cheeks flushed. Now and then she moved and he changed his arm a little, and once he kissed her dark shining hair. The afternoon had made them tranquil for a while, as if to give them a deep memory for the long parting the next day promised. They had never been closer in their month of love, nor communicated more profoundly one with another, than when she brushed silent lips against his coat’s shoulder or when he touched the end of her fingers, gently, as though she were asleep.

events.title: War, Oxford, Daisy's Impatience, and Gatsby's Return
detailed_summary: Gatsby performed well in the war, reaching the rank of Major, but complications sent him to Oxford afterwards instead of home.
Daisy's letters became nervously desperate; she felt external pressures and needed Gatsby's reassurance.
Her world of privilege, parties, and social expectations pushed her towards making a decision about her life.
She resumed dating multiple men, caught between her feelings for Gatsby and the need for immediate security.
Tom Buchanan arrived, representing stability and wealth, flattering Daisy.
She married Tom, a decision likely involving both struggle and relief; Gatsby received her letter while at Oxford.
As dawn breaks at Gatsby's house, he insists to Nick that Daisy never loved Tom, or only briefly, claiming her confession was coerced.
Gatsby makes the enigmatic comment that the affair 'was just personal'.
After the war, penniless, Gatsby travelled to Louisville while Tom and Daisy were on their honeymoon.
He revisited places he and Daisy shared, finding the city imbued with melancholy beauty due to her absence.
Leaving Louisville by train, he felt he hadn't searched hard enough, that he was leaving her behind.
He watched the city fade, feeling he had lost the best part of his past forever.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: He did extraordinarily well in the war.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

events.text_segment:
He did extraordinarily well in the war. He was a captain before he went to the front, and following the Argonne battles he got his majority and the command of the divisional machine-guns. After the armistice he tried frantically to get home, but some complication or misunderstanding sent him to Oxford instead. He was worried now—there was a quality of nervous despair in Daisy’s letters. She didn’t see why he couldn’t come. She was feeling the pressure of the world outside, and she wanted to see him and feel his presence beside her and be reassured that she was doing the right thing after all.
For Daisy was young and her artificial world was redolent of orchids and pleasant, cheerful snobbery and orchestras which set the rhythm of the year, summing up the sadness and suggestiveness of life in new tunes. All night the saxophones wailed the hopeless comment of the “Beale Street Blues” while a hundred pairs of golden and silver slippers shuffled the shining dust. At the grey tea hour there were always rooms that throbbed incessantly with this low, sweet fever, while fresh faces drifted here and there like rose petals blown by the sad horns around the floor.
Through this twilight universe Daisy began to move again with the season; suddenly she was again keeping half a dozen dates a day with half a dozen men, and drowsing asleep at dawn with the beads and chiffon of an evening-dress tangled among dying orchids on the floor beside her bed. And all the time something within her was crying for a decision. She wanted her life shaped now, immediately—and the decision must be made by some force—of love, of money, of unquestionable practicality—that was close at hand.
That force took shape in the middle of spring with the arrival of Tom Buchanan. There was a wholesome bulkiness about his person and his position, and Daisy was flattered. Doubtless there was a certain struggle and a certain relief. The letter reached Gatsby while he was still at Oxford.
It was dawn now on Long Island and we went about opening the rest of the windows downstairs, filling the house with grey-turning, gold-turning light. The shadow of a tree fell abruptly across the dew and ghostly birds began to sing among the blue leaves. There was a slow, pleasant movement in the air, scarcely a wind, promising a cool, lovely day.
“I don’t think she ever loved him.” Gatsby turned around from a window and looked at me challengingly. “You must remember, old sport, she was very excited this afternoon. He told her those things in a way that frightened her—that made it look as if I was some kind of cheap sharper. And the result was she hardly knew what she was saying.”
He sat down gloomily.
“Of course she might have loved him just for a minute, when they were first married—and loved me more even then, do you see?”
Suddenly he came out with a curious remark.
“In any case,” he said, “it was just personal.”
What could you make of that, except to suspect some intensity in his conception of the affair that couldn’t be measured?
He came back from France when Tom and Daisy were still on their wedding trip, and made a miserable but irresistible journey to Louisville on the last of his army pay. He stayed there a week, walking the streets where their footsteps had clicked together through the November night and revisiting the out-of-the-way places to which they had driven in her white car. Just as Daisy’s house had always seemed to him more mysterious and gay than other houses, so his idea of the city itself, even though she was gone from it, was pervaded with a melancholy beauty.
He left feeling that if he had searched harder, he might have found her—that he was leaving her behind. The day-coach—he was penniless now—was hot. He went out to the open vestibule and sat down on a folding-chair, and the station slid away and the backs of unfamiliar buildings moved by. Then out into the spring fields, where a yellow trolley raced them for a minute with people in it who might once have seen the pale magic of her face along the casual street.
The track curved and now it was going away from the sun, which, as it sank lower, seemed to spread itself in benediction over the vanishing city where she had drawn her breath. He stretched out his hand desperately as if to snatch only a wisp of air, to save a fragment of the spot that she had made lovely for him. But it was all going by too fast now for his blurred eyes and he knew that he had lost that part of it, the freshest and the best, forever.

He was a man who, when he chose, could be astoundingly careless with his life. But he was too big for the war, and the war was too small for him. Afterward, he went to Oxford, not because he had earned the right to go there, but because he had been given a special commission. The war had made him a major, but it had also made him a man of mystery. He was not the same man who had gone to the war. He was older, more mature, and more aware of the fragility of life. Daisy's letters to him had become increasingly desperate. She was caught in a world of privilege and expectation, and she was afraid. She needed Gatsby to reassure her, to promise her that everything would be all right. But Gatsby was away, and Daisy was left to make her own decisions. She began to date other men, not out of indifference, but out of necessity. She needed security, and Gatsby could not provide it. Tom Buchanan arrived on the scene, a man of wealth and power, who flattered Daisy and made her feel safe. She married him, not out of love, but out of a need for stability. Gatsby received her letter while he was at Oxford, and it broke his heart. He had believed in her, in their love, and now it was gone. He claimed that her confession had been coerced, that she had been forced to choose Tom over him. He made the enigmatic comment that the affair 'was just personal.' After the war, Gatsby had gone to Louisville, where Daisy had once lived. He had revisited the places they had shared, and he had found the city imbued with a melancholy beauty. He had not searched hard enough, he realized as he left by train. He was leaving her behind, and he felt that he had lost the best part of his past forever.

events.title: Nick's Departure and Final Words to Gatsby
detailed_summary: After breakfast, the weather feels autumnal.
Gatsby's gardener plans to drain the pool, but Gatsby asks him to wait, telling Nick he hasn't used it all summer.
Nick feels reluctant to leave Gatsby for work in the city and misses several trains.
He promises to call Gatsby around noon.
As they walk down the steps, Gatsby anxiously hopes Daisy will call.
Nick reassures him.
As Nick walks away, he turns back and shouts across the lawn that Gatsby is worth more than the 'rotten crowd' he associates with.
Nick reflects that this was his only compliment to Gatsby, despite disapproving of him.
Gatsby responds with a radiant, understanding smile.
Nick remembers first arriving at Gatsby's house months earlier, contrasting the past crowds with Gatsby's solitary stance concealing his 'incorruptible dream'.
Nick thanks Gatsby for his hospitality and says goodbye.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”

events.text_segment:
It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The night had made a sharp difference in the weather and there was an autumn flavour in the air. The gardener, the last one of Gatsby’s former servants, came to the foot of the steps.
“I’m going to drain the pool today, Mr. Gatsby. Leaves’ll start falling pretty soon, and then there’s always trouble with the pipes.”
“Don’t do it today,” Gatsby answered. He turned to me apologetically. “You know, old sport, I’ve never used that pool all summer?”
I looked at my watch and stood up.
“Twelve minutes to my train.”
I didn’t want to go to the city. I wasn’t worth a decent stroke of work, but it was more than that—I didn’t want to leave Gatsby. I missed that train, and then another, before I could get myself away.
“I’ll call you up,” I said finally.
“Do, old sport.”
“I’ll call you about noon.”
We walked slowly down the steps.
“I suppose Daisy’ll call too.” He looked at me anxiously, as if he hoped I’d corroborate this.
“I suppose so.”
“Well, goodbye.”
We shook hands and I started away. Just before I reached the hedge I remembered something and turned around.
“They’re a rotten crowd,” I shouted across the lawn. “You’re worth the whole damn bunch put together.”
I’ve always been glad I said that. It was the only compliment I ever gave him, because I disapproved of him from beginning to end. First he nodded politely, and then his face broke into that radiant and understanding smile, as if we’d been in ecstatic cahoots on that fact all the time. His gorgeous pink rag of a suit made a bright spot of colour against the white steps, and I thought of the night when I first came to his ancestral home, three months before. The lawn and drive had been crowded with the faces of those who guessed at his corruption—and he had stood on those steps, concealing his incorruptible dream, as he waved them goodbye.
I thanked him for his hospitality. We were always thanking him for that—I and the others.
“Goodbye,” I called. “I enjoyed breakfast, Gatsby.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The morning was cold and grey, and the leaves were beginning to fall. Gatsby’s gardener, a solemn man with a face like a dead fish, was already at work draining the pool. Gatsby stopped him with a word, and I saw his eyes light up with a kind of wistful hope.

"I haven’t used it all summer," he said, as if that were a reason to keep it full.

I felt a sudden reluctance to go into the city. I missed several trains, and finally gave it up and walked back to Gatsby’s house. We sat on the porch and talked, and I promised to call him around noon.

As we walked down the steps, Gatsby stood there, his face alight with the old, familiar hope. He was waiting for Daisy to call. I reassured him as best I could, but I knew it was no use. As I turned away, I shouted across the lawn, "You’re worth the whole rotten crowd, old sport!"

It was the only time I ever told him that. I had never liked or approved of him, but I had a feeling that if I could find him in some dramatic emergency, I would be one of the very few who would take his part.

He smiled at me across the lawn, his face so radiant that I felt a sudden, inexplicable joy. I remembered the first time I had come to his house, the way the lights had been blazing and the music had been playing, and the way the people had laughed and danced. Now it was all over, and he stood alone, guarding his dream.

I thanked him for his hospitality and said goodbye.

I promised to call him around noon. As we walked down the steps, Gatsby stood there, his face alight with the old, familiar hope. He was waiting for Daisy to call. I reassured him as best I could, but I knew it was no use. As I turned away, I shouted across the lawn, 'You’re worth the whole rotten crowd, old sport!' It was the only time I ever told him that. I had never liked or approved of him, but I had a feeling that if I could find him in some dramatic emergency, I would be one of the very few who would take his part. He smiled at me across the lawn, his face so radiant that I felt a sudden, inexplicable joy. I remembered the first time I had come to his house, the way the lights had been blazing and the music had been playing, and the way the people had laughed and danced. Now it was all over, and he stood alone, guarding his dream. I thanked him for his hospitality and said goodbye.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It was nine o’clock when we finished breakfast and went out on the porch. The morning was still and golden, the kind of morning that made you feel as if the world had just been created and everything was new and full of promise. Gatsby stood by the steps, his eyes fixed on the water beyond the bay, where the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock flickered like a secret. I watched him, wondering how much of his dream was still alive in that quiet moment, how much of it had already been lost to time and longing.

Nick lit a cigarette and leaned against the railing, the salt air filling his lungs. “He’s waiting for her,” he said quietly, more to himself than to me. “He always is.”

I didn’t say anything. There was nothing to say. Gatsby had built his world around that one woman, that one hope, and no matter how much he had, it was never enough. He had money, power, parties that never ended, but none of it mattered if Daisy wasn’t there to see it.

The sun climbed higher, casting long shadows across the lawn. A breeze stirred the trees, and for a moment, I thought I heard her laugh—soft, distant, like a memory. But it was only the wind.

Gatsby turned to us then, his smile a little too bright, a little too practiced. “I think I’ll go in,” he said. “There’s a letter I need to write.”

He disappeared into the house, and the silence stretched between Nick and me. It was the kind of silence that spoke volumes, the kind that made you feel like you were standing on the edge of something you couldn’t quite understand.

I looked out at the water again, at the green light that had become a symbol of everything Gatsby wanted and never could have. And I wondered if, in the end, it was ever enough to just dream.

events.title: Nick's Distracted Day and Breakup with Jordan
detailed_summary: In the city, Nick is unable to focus on work and falls asleep.
He's awakened by a phone call from Jordan Baker just before noon.
Jordan sounds harsh and dry, unlike her usual cool tone.
She informs Nick she has left Daisy's house and is heading to Southampton.
Nick is annoyed by her departure from Daisy's.
Jordan confronts Nick about his behavior the previous night.
Their conversation becomes stilted and awkward as they arrange, then cancel, plans to meet.
The call ends abruptly, with Nick realizing their relationship is over and feeling indifferent.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.

events.text_segment:
Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair. Just before noon the phone woke me, and I started up with sweat breaking out on my forehead. It was Jordan Baker; she often called me up at this hour because the uncertainty of her own movements between hotels and clubs and private houses made her hard to find in any other way. Usually her voice came over the wire as something fresh and cool, as if a divot from a green golf-links had come sailing in at the office window, but this morning it seemed harsh and dry.
“I’ve left Daisy’s house,” she said. “I’m at Hempstead, and I’m going down to Southampton this afternoon.”
Probably it had been tactful to leave Daisy’s house, but the act annoyed me, and her next remark made me rigid.
“You weren’t so nice to me last night.”
“How could it have mattered then?”
Silence for a moment. Then:
“However—I want to see you.”
“I want to see you, too.”
“Suppose I don’t go to Southampton, and come into town this afternoon?”
“No—I don’t think this afternoon.”
“Very well.”
“It’s impossible this afternoon. Various—”
We talked like that for a while, and then abruptly we weren’t talking any longer. I don’t know which of us hung up with a sharp click, but I know I didn’t care. I couldn’t have talked to her across a tea-table that day if I never talked to her again in this world.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Up in the city, I tried for a while to list the quotations on an interminable amount of stock, then I fell asleep in my swivel-chair. I was awakened by a phone call just before noon. It was Jordan, and she spoke in a harsh, dry way that was unlike her usual cool tone. "I just left Daisy's," she said. "I'm going to Southampton this afternoon." I was annoyed by this, because I had thought she was going to stay with Daisy until the weekend. "Well," I said, "I hope you have a good time." There was a pause, and then she said, "I wanted to talk to you about last night." I felt a coldness in my chest. "I don't think there's anything to talk about," I said. "I think we're both tired." "I don't think we are," she said. "I think we're both being very careful." The conversation became stilted and awkward as we arranged, then canceled, plans to meet. Finally, she said, "I guess this is it, then," and hung up. I sat there for a long time, the phone still in my hand, and realized that something had ended between us. I felt nothing, really—just a kind of quiet indifference, as if I were watching something happen to someone else.
