When I awoke, the room was still and the silence was oppressive. The numbers on the ticker had long since stopped moving, and the only sound was the faint ticking of the clock on the wall. I felt a strange sense of detachment, as if I had been watching the world from behind a glass wall. It was then that I realized how hollow the pursuit of wealth and status had become. The excitement of the stock market, the thrill of speculation, had all faded into a dull ache. I thought of Gatsby, of his grand parties and his unending hope for Daisy, and I felt a pang of sorrow for the dream he had chased so desperately. The American Dream, once so bright and full of promise, now seemed tarnished and unattainable. I remembered the green light at the end of Daisy's dock, flickering like a distant star, and I understood that Gatsby had reached for something that could never truly be his. The dream was gone, and with it, the man who had embodied it. I sat there in the stillness, the weight of the moment pressing down on me, and I knew that I would never see Gatsby again. The city outside was still alive with noise and movement, but inside, I was alone with my thoughts and the fading echoes of a dream that had once seemed so real.

events.title: Failed Call to Gatsby and Wilson's Grief-Stricken Vigil
detailed_summary: Nick attempts to call Gatsby several times but finds the line busy, eventually learning it's held for a long-distance call from Detroit.
He plans to take the 3:50 train.
The narrative shifts focus back to the previous night at Wilson's garage after the accident.
Nick reflects on passing the ash-heaps earlier, deliberately avoiding the scene.
Myrtle's sister, Catherine, arrived drunk and distraught, fainting when told the ambulance had already left.
George Wilson remained inside the garage, rocking in grief, while a crowd gathered outside.
Michaelis, the neighboring restaurant owner, stayed with Wilson throughout the night, along with a few other men initially.
Eventually, Michaelis sent the last stranger away and remained alone with Wilson until dawn, making coffee to stay awake.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.

events.text_segment:
I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I tried four times; finally an exasperated central told me the wire was being kept open for long distance from Detroit. Taking out my timetable, I drew a small circle around the three-fifty train. Then I leaned back in my chair and tried to think. It was just noon.
When I passed the ash-heaps on the train that morning I had crossed deliberately to the other side of the car. I supposed there’d be a curious crowd around there all day with little boys searching for dark spots in the dust, and some garrulous man telling over and over what had happened, until it became less and less real even to him and he could tell it no longer, and Myrtle Wilson’s tragic achievement was forgotten. Now I want to go back a little and tell what happened at the garage after we left there the night before.
They had difficulty in locating the sister, Catherine. She must have broken her rule against drinking that night, for when she arrived she was stupid with liquor and unable to understand that the ambulance had already gone to Flushing. When they convinced her of this, she immediately fainted, as if that was the intolerable part of the affair. Someone, kind or curious, took her in his car and drove her in the wake of her sister’s body.
Until long after midnight a changing crowd lapped up against the front of the garage, while George Wilson rocked himself back and forth on the couch inside. For a while the door of the office was open, and everyone who came into the garage glanced irresistibly through it. Finally someone said it was a shame, and closed the door. Michaelis and several other men were with him; first, four or five men, later two or three men. Still later Michaelis had to ask the last stranger to wait there fifteen minutes longer, while he went back to his own place and made a pot of coffee. After that, he stayed there alone with Wilson until dawn.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
I called Gatsby’s house a few minutes later, but the line was busy. I called again at five minutes to three, and again at five minutes to four, and again at five minutes to five, and each time the line was busy. Finally, I called at five minutes to six, and a voice said, “This is the operator. The line is held for a long-distance call from Detroit.”

I decided to take the 3:50 train. I had a feeling that the past was closing in on me, and I wanted to get away before it could catch up. But as I walked toward the station, I found myself passing the ash-heaps again, and I hesitated. I had avoided this place all day, as if it were some kind of forbidden ground. But now I felt drawn to it, as if something were calling me from the smoke and dust.

The previous night, after the accident, the garage had been a scene of chaos and grief. Myrtle’s sister, Catherine, had arrived drunk and distraught, and when she was told the ambulance had already left, she fainted. George Wilson remained inside, rocking in a chair, his face pale and his eyes empty. A crowd had gathered outside, whispering and staring, but no one dared to enter.

Michaelis, the owner of the restaurant next door, had stayed with Wilson throughout the night, along with a few other men who had come to see what was happening. But as the hours passed, the others drifted away, and Michaelis was left alone with Wilson. He made coffee to keep himself awake, and he sat with the man in silence, watching the dawn break over the ash-heaps and the desolate landscape beyond.

What was Gatsby doing alone in his house at this hour? Who was the man he was talking to? I knew I had to find out more, but I also knew I had to be careful. Gatsby was a man of secrets, and I had the feeling that whatever was going on was not going to end well. I decided to wait until morning before approaching him again. As I drove home, I couldn’t shake the feeling that something was about to change, and I wasn’t sure if I was ready for it.

events.title: Wilson's Dawning Suspicion and Ominous Resolve
detailed_summary: Around 3 a.m., Wilson grows quieter and starts talking about the yellow car, claiming he knows how to find its owner.
He mentions Myrtle returning from the city months ago with bruises.
Overcome with grief, he cries out again.
Michaelis tries to distract Wilson with questions about his marriage and children.
Michaelis feels uneasy, disturbed by passing cars and the stained workbench where Myrtle's body lay.
He suggests calling a priest, but Wilson says he doesn't belong to a church.
Wilson directs Michaelis to a drawer containing a small, expensive, new-looking dog leash braided with silver.
Wilson reveals he found it the previous afternoon and suspected something 'funny'.
Michaelis offers innocent explanations, but Wilson, likely having heard similar excuses from Myrtle, becomes distressed again.
Wilson suddenly declares, 'Then he killed her,' convinced it wasn't an accident.
He believes Myrtle ran out to speak to the man in the car who wouldn't stop.
Wilson begins rocking again.
As dawn breaks, Wilson looks out at the ash-heaps.
He mutters about confronting Myrtle, telling her she couldn't fool God.
He walks to the window, indicating he told her this while looking out.
Michaelis realizes with shock that Wilson is staring directly at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg on the billboard.
Wilson repeats, 'God sees everything,' while Michaelis weakly insists it's just an advertisement.
Wilson remains at the window, nodding into the twilight.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.

events.text_segment:
About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car. He announced that he had a way of finding out whom the yellow car belonged to, and then he blurted out that a couple of months ago his wife had come from the city with her face bruised and her nose swollen.
But when he heard himself say this, he flinched and began to cry “Oh, my God!” again in his groaning voice. Michaelis made a clumsy attempt to distract him.
“How long have you been married, George? Come on there, try and sit still a minute, and answer my question. How long have you been married?”
“Twelve years.”
“Ever had any children? Come on, George, sit still—I asked you a question. Did you ever have any children?”
The hard brown beetles kept thudding against the dull light, and whenever Michaelis heard a car go tearing along the road outside it sounded to him like the car that hadn’t stopped a few hours before. He didn’t like to go into the garage, because the work bench was stained where the body had been lying, so he moved uncomfortably around the office—he knew every object in it before morning—and from time to time sat down beside Wilson trying to keep him more quiet.
“Have you got a church you go to sometimes, George? Maybe even if you haven’t been there for a long time? Maybe I could call up the church and get a priest to come over and he could talk to you, see?”
“Don’t belong to any.”
“You ought to have a church, George, for times like this. You must have gone to church once. Didn’t you get married in a church? Listen, George, listen to me. Didn’t you get married in a church?”
“That was a long time ago.”
The effort of answering broke the rhythm of his rocking—for a moment he was silent. Then the same half-knowing, half-bewildered look came back into his faded eyes.
“Look in the drawer there,” he said, pointing at the desk.
“Which drawer?”
“That drawer—that one.”
Michaelis opened the drawer nearest his hand. There was nothing in it but a small, expensive dog-leash, made of leather and braided silver. It was apparently new.
“This?” he inquired, holding it up.
Wilson stared and nodded.
“I found it yesterday afternoon. She tried to tell me about it, but I knew it was something funny.”
“You mean your wife bought it?”
“She had it wrapped in tissue paper on her bureau.”
Michaelis didn’t see anything odd in that, and he gave Wilson a dozen reasons why his wife might have bought the dog-leash. But conceivably Wilson had heard some of these same explanations before, from Myrtle, because he began saying “Oh, my God!” again in a whisper—his comforter left several explanations in the air.
“Then he killed her,” said Wilson. His mouth dropped open suddenly.
“Who did?”
“I have a way of finding out.”
“You’re morbid, George,” said his friend. “This has been a strain to you and you don’t know what you’re saying. You’d better try and sit quiet till morning.”
“He murdered her.”
“It was an accident, George.”
Wilson shook his head. His eyes narrowed and his mouth widened slightly with the ghost of a superior “Hm!”
“I know,” he said definitely. “I’m one of these trusting fellas and I don’t think any harm to nobody, but when I get to know a thing I know it. It was the man in that car. She ran out to speak to him and he wouldn’t stop.”
Michaelis had seen this too, but it hadn’t occurred to him that there was any special significance in it. He believed that Mrs. Wilson had been running away from her husband, rather than trying to stop any particular car.
“How could she of been like that?”
“She’s a deep one,” said Wilson, as if that answered the question. “Ah-h-h—”
He began to rock again, and Michaelis stood twisting the leash in his hand.
“Maybe you got some friend that I could telephone for, George?”
This was a forlorn hope—he was almost sure that Wilson had no friend: there was not enough of him for his wife. He was glad a little later when he noticed a change in the room, a blue quickening by the window, and realized that dawn wasn’t far off. About five o’clock it was blue enough outside to snap off the light.
Wilson’s glazed eyes turned out to the ash-heaps, where small grey clouds took on fantastic shapes and scurried here and there in the faint dawn wind.
“I spoke to her,” he muttered, after a long silence. “I told her she might fool me but she couldn’t fool God. I took her to the window”—with an effort he got up and walked to the rear window and leaned with his face pressed against it—“and I said ‘God knows what you’ve been doing, everything you’ve been doing. You may fool me, but you can’t fool God!’ ”
Standing behind him, Michaelis saw with a shock that he was looking at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, which had just emerged, pale and enormous, from the dissolving night.
“God sees everything,” repeated Wilson.
“That’s an advertisement,” Michaelis assured him. Something made him turn away from the window and look back into the room. But Wilson stood there a long time, his face close to the window pane, nodding into the twilight.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
About three o’clock the quality of Wilson’s incoherent muttering changed—he grew quieter and began to talk about the yellow car. He was sitting on the edge of his bed, his hands folded in his lap, and his eyes fixed on the floor. The room was dimly lit, the only light coming from a single bulb that hung from the ceiling. The air was thick with the scent of dust and despair, and the silence between his words was more oppressive than the words themselves.

"It was yellow," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. "A beautiful yellow car. I saw it... I saw it on the road. It was going fast. Too fast. And then... and then it was gone. Just like her."

He looked up for the first time, his eyes red and bloodshot. They were the eyes of a man who had lost not only his wife but also his will to live. The yellow car had become a symbol of his grief, a tangible reminder of the tragedy that had befallen him. He had once been a man of quiet dignity, a mechanic with a steady hand and a kind heart. But now, he was a broken man, wandering through the ashes of his life.

"She was in that car," he said, his voice trembling. "I know she was. I saw the dust rise behind it. I saw the way it disappeared into the distance. And I never saw her again."

The yellow car had taken Myrtle Wilson from him, and with her, the last vestiges of his hope. He had searched for her, called out her name in the streets, but no one had heard him. The world had moved on, and he had been left behind, a ghost in a world that no longer had a place for him.

"I should have known," he said, his voice breaking. "I should have known she was in trouble. I should have known she was unhappy. But I was too blind to see it."

He had always believed that love was enough, that if he worked hard and stayed by her side, she would never leave him. But love, he had learned, was not enough. It was not enough to hold a marriage together when the heart had long since wandered elsewhere. It was not enough to protect a man from the pain of betrayal and loss.

"I should have stopped her," he said, his voice barely audible. "I should have stopped her before she got in that car."

The yellow car had become a symbol of his failure, a reminder of the choices he had made and the choices he had not made. It was a symbol of the life he had lost and the life he could never reclaim. And now, as he sat in the dim light of his room, he could not help but wonder if the car had been the only thing that had ever truly belonged to him.

"I don’t know what I’m going to do," he said, his voice trembling. "I don’t know where I’m going to go. I don’t know if I want to go anywhere at all."

He had no family, no friends, no future. He was a man without a purpose, a man without a home. The yellow car had taken everything from him, and now he was left with nothing but the memory of what had been. And yet, even in his despair, he could not help but feel a strange sense of peace. For in the end, the yellow car had given him something, even if it was only the knowledge that he had loved her once, and that love had been enough to last a lifetime.

"I loved her," he said, his voice barely a whisper. "I loved her more than anything in the world."

And with that, he sat in silence, the only sound in the room the soft ticking of the clock on the wall. The yellow car had taken her from him, but it had also given him a final truth: that love, even in its most painful form, was the only thing that truly mattered. And as he sat there, in the dim light of his room, he could not help but wonder if, in some strange way, the yellow car had been the only thing that had ever truly belonged to him.

events.title: Wilson's Disappearance, Search, and Gatsby's Final Swim
detailed_summary: By six a.m., Michaelis is exhausted; another man arrives, and they eat breakfast while Wilson is quieter.
Michaelis goes home to sleep.
When Michaelis returns four hours later, Wilson is gone.
Wilson's movements are traced on foot through Port Roosevelt and Gad's Hill, where he bought food he didn't eat.
Witnesses report seeing a man acting strangely.
He disappears for three hours; police assume he was searching garages for the yellow car, based on his statement to Michaelis.
However, no garage attendant confirms seeing him, suggesting he found the information another way.
By half-past two, Wilson is in West Egg asking for directions to Gatsby's house, indicating he now knows Gatsby's name.
Around the same time (two o'clock), Gatsby decides to go for a swim and tells the butler to bring any phone messages to the pool.
He gets the pneumatic mattress from the garage, with the chauffeur helping inflate it.
Gatsby instructs that his main car (the one involved in the accident) not be taken out, despite needing fender repair.
He carries the mattress towards the pool alone, disappearing among the trees.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

events.text_segment:
By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. It was one of the watchers of the night before who had promised to come back, so he cooked breakfast for three, which he and the other man ate together. Wilson was quieter now, and Michaelis went home to sleep; when he awoke four hours later and hurried back to the garage, Wilson was gone.
His movements—he was on foot all the time—were afterward traced to Port Roosevelt and then to Gad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich that he didn’t eat, and a cup of coffee. He must have been tired and walking slowly, for he didn’t reach Gad’s Hill until noon. Thus far there was no difficulty in accounting for his time—there were boys who had seen a man “acting sort of crazy,” and motorists at whom he stared oddly from the side of the road. Then for three hours he disappeared from view. The police, on the strength of what he said to Michaelis, that he “had a way of finding out,” supposed that he spent that time going from garage to garage thereabout, inquiring for a yellow car. On the other hand, no garage man who had seen him ever came forward, and perhaps he had an easier, surer way of finding out what he wanted to know. By half-past two he was in West Egg, where he asked someone the way to Gatsby’s house. So by that time he knew Gatsby’s name.
At two o’clock Gatsby put on his bathing-suit and left word with the butler that if anyone phoned word was to be brought to him at the pool. He stopped at the garage for a pneumatic mattress that had amused his guests during the summer, and the chauffeur helped him to pump it up. Then he gave instructions that the open car wasn’t to be taken out under any circumstances—and this was strange, because the front right fender needed repair.
Gatsby shouldered the mattress and started for the pool. Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. Another man got out and came in, and they ate breakfast while Wilson, who had been silent all morning, sat at the table with his eyes fixed on the floor. When the meal was over, Michaelis went home to sleep. He returned four hours later and found Wilson gone. Wilson’s movements were traced on foot through Port Roosevelt and Gad’s Hill, where he had bought food he did not eat. Witnesses reported seeing a man acting strangely, and he disappeared for three hours. The police assumed he had been searching garages for the yellow car, as he had told Michaelis he would. But no garage attendant could confirm that he had been there, suggesting he had found the information another way. By half-past two, Wilson was in West Egg, asking for directions to Gatsby’s house. He now knew Gatsby’s name. Around the same time, two o’clock, Gatsby decided to go for a swim and told the butler to bring any phone messages to the pool. He got the pneumatic mattress from the garage, and the chauffeur helped him inflate it. Gatsby instructed that his main car, the one involved in the accident, not be taken out, despite needing fender repair. He carried the mattress toward the pool alone, disappearing among the trees.

- The completion invents a detail about Wilson sitting at the table with his eyes fixed on the floor, which is not present in the original passage.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:

- The completion does not specify that Wilson bought a sandwich and a cup of coffee, only mentioning food in general, and omits the detail that he did not eat the sandwich.
- The completion does not include the information about the boys and motorists who saw Wilson and their specific observations, only summarizing that witnesses saw a man acting strangely.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. He went to the window and saw that it was George Wilson, who was followed by a man in a dark suit. They came up the steps slowly, and George looked as if he had not slept for days. The man in the dark suit was Mr. Gatz, Gatsby’s father, who had come from Minnesota to see the funeral. He was a small, frail man, with a kind face and a voice that trembled with emotion. He had traveled all the way to West Egg, carrying a small valise and a photograph of his son as a young man. He had heard of Gatsby’s death from the newspapers, and he had come to claim what was left of him.

Michaelis led them into the house, and they sat in the parlor, which was still in the same state of disorder as when Gatsby had died. The room was silent, and the only sound was the ticking of the clock on the wall. Mr. Gatz looked around with a mixture of pride and sorrow, as if he were seeing his son’s life for the first time. He ran his hand over the books on the shelves, the expensive furniture, the photographs of Gatsby in uniform. He spoke of his son’s ambition, of the way he had always dreamed of something more than the life he had been born into. He spoke of the letter Gatsby had written to him when he was a boy, promising that he would make something of himself.

George Wilson sat in silence, his face pale and drawn. He had come to see the man who had killed his wife, and he had found only a dead man and a broken house. He had no words for the man who had caused his suffering, and he left without a farewell. Mr. Gatz stayed a little longer, looking at the photograph of his son, and then he too left, carrying with him the memory of a life that had been both grand and tragic.

events.title: The Holocaust: Gatsby's Death and Wilson's Suicide
detailed_summary: No phone call comes for Gatsby; the butler waits until four o'clock.
Nick speculates Gatsby no longer expected the call or cared, having perhaps realized his dream was lost and the real world felt alien and grotesque.
He imagines Gatsby perceiving the world as 'material without being real,' filled with 'poor ghosts,' anticipating the 'ashen, fantastic figure' (Wilson) approaching.
The chauffeur hears shots but doesn't initially react.
Nick arrives from the station, his anxious rush up the steps alarming the staff, who Nick believes already suspected the worst.
Nick, the chauffeur, butler, and gardener hurry to the pool.
They find Gatsby's body on the mattress, drifting irregularly in the pool.
A small gust of wind and leaves disturb the mattress's course, tracing a thin red circle in the water from his blood.
As they carry Gatsby's body towards the house, the gardener discovers Wilson's body nearby in the grass.
The murder-suicide is complete.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

events.text_segment:
No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. I have an idea that Gatsby himself didn’t believe it would come, and perhaps he no longer cared. If that was true he must have felt that he had lost the old warm world, paid a high price for living too long with a single dream. He must have looked up at an unfamiliar sky through frightening leaves and shivered as he found what a grotesque thing a rose is and how raw the sunlight was upon the scarcely created grass. A new world, material without being real, where poor ghosts, breathing dreams like air, drifted fortuitously about… like that ashen, fantastic figure gliding toward him through the amorphous trees.
The chauffeur—he was one of Wolfshiem’s protégés—heard the shots—afterwards he could only say that he hadn’t thought anything much about them. I drove from the station directly to Gatsby’s house and my rushing anxiously up the front steps was the first thing that alarmed anyone. But they knew then, I firmly believe. With scarcely a word said, four of us, the chauffeur, butler, gardener, and I hurried down to the pool.
There was a faint, barely perceptible movement of the water as the fresh flow from one end urged its way toward the drain at the other. With little ripples that were hardly the shadows of waves, the laden mattress moved irregularly down the pool. A small gust of wind that scarcely corrugated the surface was enough to disturb its accidental course with its accidental burden. The touch of a cluster of leaves revolved it slowly, tracing, like the leg of transit, a thin red circle in the water.
It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. I suppose he thought Gatsby was waiting for a call from Daisy, but Daisy had gone away to the city with Tom, and there was no one left in the house but the servants. I think Gatsby suspected he was going to die soon. He had waited all summer for something that was never going to happen, and now he must have felt the world was a strange and empty place. I imagine he looked out at the water and saw it all—how the whole thing had been a mirage, a dream that had dissolved in the heat. He must have seen Wilson coming, that ashen, fantastic figure, with the gun in his hand and the wind in his hair, like some tragic character out of a bad play. The chauffeur heard the shots, but he didn’t run at first. He just stood there, as if he couldn’t believe it. Then he ran, but it was too late. I came up from the station, and the way I rushed up the steps must have frightened them, because they had already seen something was wrong. We all went to the pool—me, the chauffeur, the butler, and the gardener. Gatsby was lying on the mattress, drifting irregularly in the water, his face pale and still. A small gust of wind and some leaves disturbed the course of the mattress, and for a moment, the water traced a thin red circle around him. We pulled him out and carried him toward the house, and then the gardener found Wilson’s body in the grass nearby. The murder-suicide was complete.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. The house was silent, the lights were out, and the wind had died down, leaving only the hush of the night. He sat in the dim glow of the hall lamp, his eyes fixed on the receiver, as if by sheer will he could make it ring. The hours passed slowly, each one heavier than the last, and still the silence held. He had not moved from his post, not even to light a cigarette or check the time. The clock on the wall ticked steadily, a metronome of expectation that never fulfilled itself. He had been told to wait, and he waited. It was not the first time he had done so, nor would it be the last. In this house, where parties roared and laughter echoed through the halls by day, the nights were often spent in lonely vigil, waiting for someone who never came. The house, with all its grandeur and glamour, was a place of illusions, and he, like so many others, had become a part of that illusion. He was the unseen hand, the silent presence, the faithful shadow that followed the light. And so, he waited, not just for a message, but for the hope that it might still come, that the world of Gatsby and his dreams might still reach out to him, even in the quiet of the night.

events.title: Investigation, Isolation, and Failed Contact
detailed_summary: The days following Gatsby's death are chaotic, filled with police, media, and onlookers.
A detective labels Wilson a 'madman', setting the tone for inaccurate newspaper reports.
Catherine lies at the inquest, claiming Myrtle was happy with Wilson and never knew Gatsby, effectively simplifying the case to murder-suicide driven by grief.
Catherine's performance convinces the authorities and she portrays herself as deeply mourning her sister.
Nick finds himself aligned with the deceased Gatsby and feels isolated as the sole person truly interested in him.
All inquiries about Gatsby are directed to Nick, solidifying his sense of responsibility.
Nick instinctively calls Daisy shortly after finding Gatsby's body, only to learn she and Tom have left town without a forwarding address or return date.
The Buchanans' departure leaves Nick unable to reach them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Can’t say.”

events.text_segment:
After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. A rope stretched across the main gate and a policeman by it kept out the curious, but little boys soon discovered that they could enter through my yard, and there were always a few of them clustered open-mouthed about the pool. Someone with a positive manner, perhaps a detective, used the expression “madman” as he bent over Wilson’s body that afternoon, and the adventitious authority of his voice set the key for the newspaper reports next morning.
Most of those reports were a nightmare—grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. When Michaelis’s testimony at the inquest brought to light Wilson’s suspicions of his wife I thought the whole tale would shortly be served up in racy pasquinade—but Catherine, who might have said anything, didn’t say a word. She showed a surprising amount of character about it too—looked at the coroner with determined eyes under that corrected brow of hers, and swore that her sister had never seen Gatsby, that her sister was completely happy with her husband, that her sister had been into no mischief whatever. She convinced herself of it, and cried into her handkerchief, as if the very suggestion was more than she could endure. So Wilson was reduced to a man “deranged by grief” in order that the case might remain in its simplest form. And it rested there.
But all this part of it seemed remote and unessential. I found myself on Gatsby’s side, and alone. From the moment I telephoned news of the catastrophe to West Egg village, every surmise about him, and every practical question, was referred to me. At first I was surprised and confused; then, as he lay in his house and didn’t move or breathe or speak, hour upon hour, it grew upon me that I was responsible, because no one else was interested—interested, I mean, with that intense personal interest to which everyone has some vague right at the end.
I called up Daisy half an hour after we found him, called her instinctively and without hesitation. But she and Tom had gone away early that afternoon, and taken baggage with them.
“Left no address?”
“No.”
“Say when they’d be back?”
“No.”
“Any idea where they are? How I could reach them?”
“I don’t know. Can’t say.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. The house was full of strangers who had never seen him alive, picking over the fragments of his life with the curiosity of archaeologists. The newspapers were full of him too, but in a different way. They made him a kind of tragic romantic figure, a man who had loved too much and died for it. The truth was less poetic. The truth was that Jay Gatsby, of West Egg and the whole crass world he had tried so hard to rise above, was dead, and the only human being left to mourn him was his friend Nick Carraway.

The inquest was a farce. The only witness of any importance was Catherine, who gave a performance that would have done credit to a stage actress. She said Myrtle had never known Gatsby, that she had been perfectly happy with her husband, and that the whole thing was a case of mistaken identity. The police, the reporters, and the coroner all seemed to believe her. She was a convincing liar, and she played her part to the hilt. She wept openly, and when the verdict of suicide was given, she collapsed in a faint.

I found myself in a curious position. I was the only one who had known Gatsby at all, and I was the only one who seemed to care. The others had come and gone, like moths drawn to a flame, and now they were gone. I was left with the ashes. I had the feeling that I was the only one who could tell the story, and that I had to do it before it was too late. I had the feeling that Gatsby had reached out to me once, in the middle of the night, and that I had failed him.

I called Daisy that night, as soon as I found out about Gatsby. I wanted to see her, to talk to her, to know what she had done. But she had gone. She and Tom had left town, and no one knew where they were going or when they would be back. They had left without a word, without a note, without a forwarding address. It was as if they had never been there at all. And I was left with the feeling that they had never really loved him at all.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. The house was no longer a place of enchantment but a scene of violent, grotesque realism. The reporters, with their loud voices and hungry eyes, turned Gatsby’s mansion into a theater of the macabre. They asked questions that had no answers, and they wrote stories that twisted the truth into something unrecognizable. The once-gilded halls, where laughter and music had flowed like wine, now echoed with the clatter of typewriters and the flash of cameras. Gatsby’s guests, who had once flocked to his parties in droves, now came only to gawk, to see the spectacle of a man who had become a legend in death. Some of them had never even met him, yet they claimed to know his secrets. Others, who had once danced in his ballroom, now whispered about him as if he were a ghost. The funeral was a quiet affair, attended only by a handful of people. Owl Eyes, the man who had once praised Gatsby’s library for its authenticity, was there. So was Gatsby’s father, Henry C. Gatz, who had traveled from Minnesota to see his son one last time. But most of the people who had once called Gatsby their friend were nowhere to be found. The newspapers had moved on to the next scandal, the next tragedy, the next story that would sell papers. Gatsby’s name, once spoken with admiration and envy, was now a footnote in the city’s endless gossip. And I, Nick Carraway, who had once believed in the American Dream, now saw it for what it was: a dream that could never be fully realized, a dream that was always just out of reach. I left West Egg soon after, leaving behind the glittering facade of Gatsby’s world and the illusion of a life that could be remade. I returned to the Midwest, to the quiet simplicity of a life that, though less glamorous, was more honest. And I carried with me the memory of Gatsby, a man who had reached for the stars and was crushed by the weight of his own ambition.

events.title: Seeking Support and Facing Indifference
detailed_summary: Nick feels a strong urge to find someone to support Gatsby, even in death, imagining reassuring Gatsby himself.
He tries to contact Meyer Wolfshiem, obtaining his office number after finding he's unlisted, but gets no answer after hours.
Nick feels haunted by Gatsby's imagined plea for help and companionship.
He searches Gatsby's desk for contact information for his parents but finds only Dan Cody's picture.
The next morning, Nick sends the butler to New York with a letter urging Wolfshiem to come.
Neither Wolfshiem nor Daisy contacts Nick as he expected; only more officials arrive.
The butler returns with Wolfshiem's written reply expressing shock but stating he's too busy with important business to get involved.
Wolfshiem asks to be kept informed about the funeral via letter through 'Edgar' and claims ignorance of Gatsby's family.
Nick feels defiant solidarity with Gatsby against the indifferent world.
An unexpected long-distance call comes through, initially thought to be Daisy, but it's a man named Slagle from Chicago.
Slagle, unaware of Gatsby's death, speaks rapidly about 'Young Parke' being arrested in a bond scheme.
Nick interrupts to inform Slagle that Gatsby is dead, leading to silence and an abrupt disconnection.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I wanted to get somebody for him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

events.text_segment:
I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him: “I’ll get somebody for you, Gatsby. Don’t worry. Just trust me and I’ll get somebody for you—”
Meyer Wolfshiem’s name wasn’t in the phone book. The butler gave me his office address on Broadway, and I called Information, but by the time I had the number it was long after five, and no one answered the phone.
“Will you ring again?”
“I’ve rung three times.”
“It’s very important.”
“Sorry. I’m afraid no one’s there.”
I went back to the drawing-room and thought for an instant that they were chance visitors, all these official people who suddenly filled it. But, though they drew back the sheet and looked at Gatsby with shocked eyes, his protest continued in my brain:
“Look here, old sport, you’ve got to get somebody for me. You’ve got to try hard. I can’t go through this alone.”
Someone started to ask me questions, but I broke away and going upstairs looked hastily through the unlocked parts of his desk—he’d never told me definitely that his parents were dead. But there was nothing—only the picture of Dan Cody, a token of forgotten violence, staring down from the wall.
Next morning I sent the butler to New York with a letter to Wolfshiem, which asked for information and urged him to come out on the next train. That request seemed superfluous when I wrote it. I was sure he’d start when he saw the newspapers, just as I was sure there’d be a wire from Daisy before noon—but neither a wire nor Mr. Wolfshiem arrived; no one arrived except more police and photographers and newspaper men. When the butler brought back Wolfshiem’s answer I began to have a feeling of defiance, of scornful solidarity between Gatsby and me against them all.
Dear Mr. Carraway. This has been one of the most terrible shocks of my life to me I hardly can believe it that it is true at all. Such a mad act as that man did should make us all think. I cannot come down now as I am tied up in some very important business and cannot get mixed up in this thing now. If there is anything I can do a little later let me know in a letter by Edgar. I hardly know where I am when I hear about a thing like this and am completely knocked down and out.
Yours truly
Meyer Wolfshiem
and then hasty addenda beneath:
Let me know about the funeral etc do not know his family at all.
When the phone rang that afternoon and Long Distance said Chicago was calling I thought this would be Daisy at last. But the connection came through as a man’s voice, very thin and far away.
“This is Slagle speaking…”
“Yes?” The name was unfamiliar.
“Hell of a note, isn’t it? Get my wire?”
“There haven’t been any wires.”
“Young Parke’s in trouble,” he said rapidly. “They picked him up when he handed the bonds over the counter. They got a circular from New York giving ’em the numbers just five minutes before. What d’you know about that, hey? You never can tell in these hick towns—”
“Hello!” I interrupted breathlessly. “Look here—this isn’t Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby’s dead.”
There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: I wanted to get somebody for him. It was a strange idea, but somehow it seemed to fit. I had always felt that Gatsby was a man who could not be alone. He needed someone to believe in him, to understand the dream he carried in his heart. I thought of Daisy, of course, but she was gone, and the Gatsby I had known in West Egg was already a ghost, a man who had lost his way in the past. I thought of Jordan, but she was too sharp, too cynical, and I knew she would never stay. I thought of many others, but none of them seemed right. It was as if Gatsby needed someone who could see through the illusion, who could love him not for the man he pretended to be, but for the man he truly was. I thought of Nick, but he was too much of an observer, too distant. He had tried to reach Gatsby, but Gatsby had always been just out of his grasp. And then I thought of someone else—someone who had been there at the beginning, someone who had seen Gatsby not as a king of the East Egg, but as a boy with a dream. I thought of Owl Eyes, perhaps, or even the Wilsons, but they were too broken, too lost. I thought of the people who had come and gone at his parties, the ones who had laughed and danced and then disappeared, leaving nothing behind. I thought of the people who had taken from him and given nothing in return. And then I thought of someone else—someone who had never asked for anything, who had never taken, who had simply been there. I thought of the girl from the city, the one who had once sat with me in the garden and listened to the stories of Gatsby’s past. She had been quiet, but she had listened. She had not laughed at his dreams, nor had she dismissed them. She had simply listened, and in that silence, I thought I saw something that might have been hope. I thought of her again and again, and each time, I felt a little more certain. She was not perfect, of course. No one was. But she was kind, and she was real, and she had a way of seeing people that was not clouded by the illusions of wealth or status. I thought of how Gatsby had always been searching for something—something that was just out of reach. And I thought of how, perhaps, this girl could be the one to help him find it. I did not know if she would say yes, or if she even knew who Gatsby was. But I thought it was worth trying. I thought it was worth the risk. Because Gatsby deserved to be loved—not for the man he had become, but for the man he had always been. And if there was even a chance that someone could see that, I wanted to find them for him. I wanted to get somebody for him.

events.title: Arrival of Gatsby's Father
detailed_summary: On the third day, a telegram arrives from Henry C. Gatz in Minnesota, identifying himself as Gatsby's father and requesting the funeral be postponed until his arrival.
Mr. Gatz arrives, appearing elderly, helpless, and overwhelmed, inappropriately dressed in a heavy coat for the warm weather.
He is visibly emotional, his eyes tearing up, and he nervously pulls at his beard.
Nick takes him inside, offering food and drink, but Mr. Gatz is too distraught to eat or drink steadily.
He explains he learned about his son's death from the Chicago newspaper and came immediately.
Mr. Gatz refers to Wilson as a 'madman'.
Nick leads Mr. Gatz to the drawing-room where Gatsby's body lies and leaves him alone there.
After some time, Mr. Gatz emerges, his initial grief mingling with awe and pride as he takes in the grandeur of Gatsby's house.
Nick helps him upstairs to a bedroom.
Mr. Gatz confirms his name is Gatz, not Gatsby.
He dismisses Nick's suggestion of taking the body West, stating Jimmy (Gatsby) preferred the East where he achieved success.
He proudly speaks of his son's potential, believing he would have been a great man like James J. Hill and contributed significantly to the country.
Overcome with emotion and exhaustion, Mr. Gatz falls asleep almost instantly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

events.text_segment:
I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It said only that the sender was leaving immediately and to postpone the funeral until he came.
It was Gatsby’s father, a solemn old man, very helpless and dismayed, bundled up in a long cheap ulster against the warm September day. His eyes leaked continuously with excitement, and when I took the bag and umbrella from his hands he began to pull so incessantly at his sparse grey beard that I had difficulty in getting off his coat. He was on the point of collapse, so I took him into the music-room and made him sit down while I sent for something to eat. But he wouldn’t eat, and the glass of milk spilled from his trembling hand.
“I saw it in the Chicago newspaper,” he said. “It was all in the Chicago newspaper. I started right away.”
“I didn’t know how to reach you.”
His eyes, seeing nothing, moved ceaselessly about the room.
“It was a madman,” he said. “He must have been mad.”
“Wouldn’t you like some coffee?” I urged him.
“I don’t want anything. I’m all right now, Mr.—”
“Carraway.”
“Well, I’m all right now. Where have they got Jimmy?”
I took him into the drawing-room, where his son lay, and left him there. Some little boys had come up on the steps and were looking into the hall; when I told them who had arrived, they went reluctantly away.
After a little while Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out, his mouth ajar, his face flushed slightly, his eyes leaking isolated and unpunctual tears. He had reached an age where death no longer has the quality of ghastly surprise, and when he looked around him now for the first time and saw the height and splendour of the hall and the great rooms opening out from it into other rooms, his grief began to be mixed with an awed pride. I helped him to a bedroom upstairs; while he took off his coat and vest I told him that all arrangements had been deferred until he came.
“I didn’t know what you’d want, Mr. Gatsby—”
“Gatz is my name.”
“—Mr. Gatz. I thought you might want to take the body West.”
He shook his head.
“Jimmy always liked it better down East. He rose up to his position in the East. Were you a friend of my boy’s, Mr.—?”
“We were close friends.”
“He had a big future before him, you know. He was only a young man, but he had a lot of brain power here.”
He touched his head impressively, and I nodded.
“If he’d of lived, he’d of been a great man. A man like James J. Hill. He’d of helped build up the country.”
“That’s true,” I said, uncomfortably.
He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

**Chapter IX**

I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It was a simple message, but it carried the weight of a man who had traveled far and fast, driven by grief and a father’s instinct to be at his son’s side. The name was unfamiliar to me at first, but it soon became clear that this was Gatsby’s father, a man who had lived in the shadow of his son’s legend and now sought to claim a piece of it in death.

When Mr. Gatz arrived, he was a study in contrasts. His clothes were too heavy for the summer heat, and his face, lined with age and worry, seemed to sag under the burden of his journey. He clutched his beard as if it were the only thing anchoring him to reality, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. I offered him food and drink, but he could not steady his hands enough to hold a glass. He was overwhelmed, not just by grief, but by the sheer scale of the world his son had left behind.

He told me he had read about his son’s death in the Chicago newspaper and had come immediately, as if the news had summoned him from the quiet of his Midwestern life. He spoke of Wilson as a “madman,” his voice trembling with a mix of anger and disbelief. I led him to the drawing-room where Gatsby lay in stillness, and for a long time, he stood alone, staring at the body of the man who had once been his son.

When he emerged, there was a strange duality in his expression—grief mingled with a kind of awe. He looked around the grand room, the opulence of Gatsby’s life laid bare, and for a moment, I saw pride in his eyes. He was not just mourning a son; he was mourning the loss of a dream that had outgrown him. I helped him upstairs to a bedroom, where he sat heavily on the edge of the bed.

He corrected me when I referred to his son as Gatsby. “No,” he said, “his name was Jimmy Gatz. Gatsby was a name he made for himself.” And then, with a voice thick with emotion, he spoke of his son’s potential. “He would have been a great man,” he said, “like James J. Hill. He would have done something for this country.” His words were both a eulogy and a testament to the man his son had become.

As the weight of the day settled on him, Mr. Gatz’s head drooped, and he fell into a deep, exhausted sleep, as if the journey had finally caught up to him. I sat beside him, watching as the man who had once raised a boy named Jimmy now rested in the house of a man who had become Gatsby.

events.title: Klipspringer's Call and Further Disillusionment
detailed_summary: That night, a nervous caller identifies himself as Klipspringer after confirming he's speaking to Nick.
Nick initially feels relieved, hoping for another attendee at Gatsby's funeral.
He informs Klipspringer about the funeral arrangements for the next day.
Klipspringer promises to tell others but sounds hesitant about attending himself.
When pressed, Klipspringer makes excuses about a prior commitment (a picnic) in Greenwich, though he says he'll 'try' to get away.
Nick reacts with disbelief ('Huh!').
Klipspringer reveals the actual reason for his call: to ask if his tennis shoes could be sent to him, as he feels 'helpless' without them.
Disgusted, Nick hangs up before Klipspringer finishes giving his address.
Nick feels ashamed on Gatsby's behalf, reflecting on another acquaintance who implied Gatsby deserved his fate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.

events.text_segment:
That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name.
“This is Mr. Carraway,” I said.
“Oh!” He sounded relieved. “This is Klipspringer.”
I was relieved too, for that seemed to promise another friend at Gatsby’s grave. I didn’t want it to be in the papers and draw a sightseeing crowd, so I’d been calling up a few people myself. They were hard to find.
“The funeral’s tomorrow,” I said. “Three o’clock, here at the house. I wish you’d tell anybody who’d be interested.”
“Oh, I will,” he broke out hastily. “Of course I’m not likely to see anybody, but if I do.”
His tone made me suspicious.
“Of course you’ll be there yourself.”
“Well, I’ll certainly try. What I called up about is—”
“Wait a minute,” I interrupted. “How about saying you’ll come?”
“Well, the fact is—the truth of the matter is that I’m staying with some people up here in Greenwich, and they rather expect me to be with them tomorrow. In fact, there’s a sort of picnic or something. Of course I’ll do my best to get away.”
I ejaculated an unrestrained “Huh!” and he must have heard me, for he went on nervously:
“What I called up about was a pair of shoes I left there. I wonder if it’d be too much trouble to have the butler send them on. You see, they’re tennis shoes, and I’m sort of helpless without them. My address is care of B. F.—”
I didn’t hear the rest of the name, because I hung up the receiver.
After that I felt a certain shame for Gatsby—one gentleman to whom I telephoned implied that he had got what he deserved. However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.

> **Chapter IX**  
>  
> That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name. I told him I was Nick Carraway, and after a pause, he identified himself as Klipspringer. For a moment, I felt a flicker of hope—perhaps there was still someone who would show up at Gatsby’s funeral.  
>  
> “I heard about the arrangements,” he said, his voice trembling slightly. “I’ll tell the others.” But there was no conviction in his tone, only the vague promise of someone who had already decided not to follow through. When I pressed him further, he hesitated, then offered a feeble excuse about a picnic in Greenwich. “I’ll try to get away,” he said, as if the words themselves could absolve him.  
>  
> I let out a sharp, incredulous “Huh!” and he must have heard it, because he didn’t respond immediately. Then, with a sudden shift in tone, he asked if I could send him his tennis shoes. “I feel helpless without them,” he said, as if this were the most important thing in the world.  
>  
> I was disgusted. Before he could finish giving me the address, I hung up. I sat in silence for a long time, the weight of the moment pressing down on me. Gatsby had given so much to so many, and now, in death, they were nothing more than ghosts, vanishing at the first sign of trouble. I thought of another acquaintance who had once implied that Gatsby had brought his fate upon himself. I felt ashamed—not for myself, but for Gatsby, for the way the world had treated him.

That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name. I told him I was Nick Carraway, and he asked if I was the one who had been talking to Gatsby. I said I was, and he said, “Oh, I see. I thought maybe it was someone else.” Then he gave his name as Michaelis, and said he had something to tell me. I asked him what it was, and he said, “It’s about the accident.” I said I was interested, and he said, “Well, I saw it happen. I saw the whole thing.” I asked him if he would come over and talk to me, and he said he would if I came to his place. I told him I would, and we arranged to meet the next day.

The next morning I went to Michaelis’s place, which was a small flat in the city. He was a Greek, and he had a wife who was also Greek. They had a small child, and the flat was full of the smell of cooking and the sound of a baby crying. Michaelis was a nervous man, and he seemed to be afraid of something. He told me that he had seen the accident, and that he had seen Gatsby and Daisy in the car. He said that Gatsby had been driving, and that Daisy had been with him. He said that they had been going fast, and that they had hit the other car. He said that the other car had been driven by a man named Wilson, and that Wilson had been killed.

I asked him if he had seen who had been in the other car, and he said he had not. He said that he had only seen the car, and that he had not seen the man inside. He said that he had heard the crash, and that he had gone out to see what had happened. He said that he had seen Gatsby and Daisy get out of the car, and that they had looked frightened. He said that they had gotten back into the car and driven away. He said that he had not seen them again.

I thanked him for his information, and I left. I was tired and confused, and I did not know what to do next. I went back to my house, and I sat on the porch and looked out at the water. I thought about Gatsby, and I thought about Daisy, and I thought about the accident. I thought about the way Gatsby had lived, and the way he had died. I thought about the way people had treated him, and the way they had treated me. I thought about the way the world was, and the way it was not. I thought about the green light, and the orgiastic future that year by year recedes before us. I thought about how we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

events.title: Confronting Meyer Wolfshiem
detailed_summary: On the morning of the funeral, Nick goes to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem personally.
He finds Wolfshiem's office, marked 'The Swastika Holding Company'.
Initially, it seems empty, but shouting reveals people behind a partition.
A secretary, Stella, appears and denies Wolfshiem is present, claiming he's in Chicago, despite sounds from within proving otherwise.
Nick insists on seeing Wolfshiem, mentioning Gatsby.
The mention of Gatsby changes Stella's demeanor, and she fetches Wolfshiem.
Wolfshiem greets Nick solemnly, offers a cigar, and reminisces about meeting Gatsby after the war – poor, decorated, but hungry.
He claims credit for Gatsby's success, stating 'I made him' and 'raised him up out of nothing'.
Wolfshiem explains he recognized Gatsby's potential and gentlemanly appearance, using his 'Oggsford' connection.
He boasts of their close association.
Nick asks Wolfshiem to attend the funeral as Gatsby's closest friend.
Wolfshiem expresses a desire to come but ultimately refuses, claiming he cannot get 'mixed up' in a man's death.
He contrasts this with his younger self, who would stick by friends 'to the bitter end'.
Seeing Wolfshiem's determination, Nick prepares to leave.
Wolfshiem advises Nick to show friendship to the living, not the dead, stating his rule is to 'let everything alone' after death.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

events.text_segment:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The door that I pushed open, on the advice of an elevator boy, was marked “The Swastika Holding Company,” and at first there didn’t seem to be anyone inside. But when I’d shouted “hello” several times in vain, an argument broke out behind a partition, and presently a lovely Jewess appeared at an interior door and scrutinized me with black hostile eyes.
“Nobody’s in,” she said. “Mr. Wolfshiem’s gone to Chicago.”
The first part of this was obviously untrue, for someone had begun to whistle “The Rosary,” tunelessly, inside.
“Please say that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.”
“I can’t get him back from Chicago, can I?”
At this moment a voice, unmistakably Wolfshiem’s, called “Stella!” from the other side of the door.
“Leave your name on the desk,” she said quickly. “I’ll give it to him when he gets back.”
“But I know he’s there.”
She took a step toward me and began to slide her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
“You young men think you can force your way in here any time,” she scolded. “We’re getting sickantired of it. When I say he’s in Chicago, he’s in Chicago.”
I mentioned Gatsby.
“Oh-h!” She looked at me over again. “Will you just—What was your name?”
She vanished. In a moment Meyer Wolfshiem stood solemnly in the doorway, holding out both hands. He drew me into his office, remarking in a reverent voice that it was a sad time for all of us, and offered me a cigar.
“My memory goes back to when first I met him,” he said. “A young major just out of the army and covered over with medals he got in the war. He was so hard up he had to keep on wearing his uniform because he couldn’t buy some regular clothes. First time I saw him was when he came into Winebrenner’s poolroom at Forty-third Street and asked for a job. He hadn’t eat anything for a couple of days. ‘Come on have some lunch with me,’ I said. He ate more than four dollars’ worth of food in half an hour.”
“Did you start him in business?” I inquired.
“Start him! I made him.”
“Oh.”
“I raised him up out of nothing, right out of the gutter. I saw right away he was a fine-appearing, gentlemanly young man, and when he told me he was at Oggsford I knew I could use him good. I got him to join the American Legion and he used to stand high there. Right off he did some work for a client of mine up to Albany. We were so thick like that in everything”—he held up two bulbous fingers—“always together.”
I wondered if this partnership had included the World’s Series transaction in 1919.
“Now he’s dead,” I said after a moment. “You were his closest friend, so I know you’ll want to come to his funeral this afternoon.”
“I’d like to come.”
“Well, come then.”
The hair in his nostrils quivered slightly, and as he shook his head his eyes filled with tears.
“I can’t do it—I can’t get mixed up in it,” he said.
“There’s nothing to get mixed up in. It’s all over now.”
“When a man gets killed I never like to get mixed up in it in any way. I keep out. When I was a young man it was different—if a friend of mine died, no matter how, I stuck with them to the end. You may think that’s sentimental, but I mean it—to the bitter end.”
I saw that for some reason of his own he was determined not to come, so I stood up.
“Are you a college man?” he inquired suddenly.
For a moment I thought he was going to suggest a “gonnegtion,” but he only nodded and shook my hand.
“Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead,” he suggested. “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. I found his office in a block of cement buildings on West Forty-fifth Street, marked in a single line of white paint on the door: THE SWASTIKA HOLDING COMPANY. It was empty, apparently, for a long time, until I shouted and a number of people behind a partition began to stir. A girl in a red dress appeared at the partition and said Mr. Wolfshiem was in Chicago. I told her I had to see him about Gatsby. The mention of Gatsby changed her tone. She went back into the office and came out with a man who had the expression of one who was always looking at the bottom of a glass. He had a face like a fine piece of cut glass, and he smiled as if he were in a dream at the memory of some long-vanished scene. “I’m Meyer Wolfshiem,” he said. “I’m Nick Carraway.” He offered me a cigar. “I knew your father,” he said. “He was a fine man. I remember when I first met Gatsby. He was a very poor young man then, but he had a lot of nerve. He was decorated in the war, you know. I made him. I raised him up out of nothing. He was a good egg, really. He had a certain quality about him, a certain charm. He had this idea of Oggsford, you see. He thought he was one of us. I used to take him around. We were very close. We were partners in a lot of things. But that’s all over now.” He looked at me with a kind of weary amusement. “You want me to go to the funeral?” I asked. “I’d like to come,” he said, “but I can’t get mixed up in a man’s death. That’s not my way. When a man’s dead, I let him go. I stick to the living. That’s my rule.” He smiled again, as if he were indulging a child. “You’re a good fellow, Nick. But don’t waste your time on the dead. They don’t need you. The living do.”

events.title: Mr. Gatz's Pride and Gatsby's Boyhood Ambitions
detailed_summary: Nick returns to West Egg amidst darkening skies and drizzle.
He finds Mr. Gatz pacing excitedly, his pride in Gatsby and his possessions growing.
Mr. Gatz eagerly shows Nick a worn photograph of Gatsby's house that Jimmy had sent him, pointing out details.
He recounts Gatsby visiting two years prior and buying him the house he currently lives in.
Mr. Gatz reflects that Gatsby's running away from home was justified by his ambition for a 'big future'.
He emphasizes Gatsby's generosity after achieving success.
Mr. Gatz then reveals an old, ragged copy of 'Hopalong Cassidy' belonging to Gatsby as a boy.
He shows Nick the back flyleaf containing a detailed daily schedule dated September 12, 1906.
The schedule includes time for exercise, study (electricity, elocution, inventions), work, and sports.
Beneath the schedule are 'General Resolves': avoiding wasted time, quitting smoking/chewing, bathing regularly, reading improving material, saving money, and being better to parents.
Mr. Gatz sees the book and its contents as proof of Jimmy's inherent drive to 'get ahead' and improve himself.
He proudly reads the items aloud, expecting Nick to be deeply impressed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

events.text_segment:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing and now he had something to show me.
“Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”
It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.
“Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”
“Very well. Had you seen him lately?”
“He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”
He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.
“Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”
He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last flyleaf was printed the word schedule, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:
Rise from bed	6:00	a.m.
Dumbell exercise and wall-scaling	6:15⁠–⁠6:30	“
Study electricity, etc.	7:15⁠–⁠8:15	“
Work	8:30⁠–⁠4:30	p.m.
Baseball and sports	4:30⁠–⁠5:00	“
Practise elocution, poise and how to attain it	5:00⁠–⁠6:00	“
Study needed inventions	7:00⁠–⁠9:00	“
General Resolves
No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
No more smokeing or chewing.
Bath every other day
Read one improving book or magazine per week
Save $5.00 [crossed out] $3.00 per week
Be better to parents
“I came across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”
“It just shows you.”
“Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”
He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. The rain was still falling when I reached the house, and the wind had risen a little. I found Mr. Gatz in the library, pacing up and down the room with a kind of feverish excitement. He was a tall, thin old man with a high, bald forehead and a pair of steel-rimmed glasses that gave him a scholarly look. He stopped when he saw me and beamed with pleasure.

"Mr. Carraway," he said, "I've been waiting for you. I want to show you something."

He led me to a small table in the corner and picked up a photograph that was already in a frame. It was a picture of Gatsby's house, taken from the lawn, and it was so worn and handled that the edges were frayed. He held it up with a kind of reverence.

"Jimmy sent this to me," he said. "He said it was the house he was going to live in when he got to be a man. Look at it, won't you?"

I looked at the photograph, but I could see nothing in it that I had not seen before. It was the same house, the same white mansion with the green lights at the end of the dock. But to Mr. Gatz it was a symbol of his son's triumph, a monument to his ambition.

"He came back two years ago," he continued, "and bought me this house. He said I had to live in something decent. He was always like that. He had to make sure his old man was taken care of."

He paused, then added, "I think he was right to run away from home. He had to get out to make something of himself."

He was proud of that, proud of the fact that his son had left the small town and the small life behind. He was proud of the way Gatsby had risen, the way he had given to others, the way he had never forgotten where he came from.

He then reached into a drawer and pulled out an old, ragged copy of 'Hopalong Cassidy.' The pages were yellowed and the binding was loose, but he handled it with the same care as the photograph.

"This was Jimmy's when he was a boy," he said. "He used to read it every night before he went to bed."

He opened the book to the back flyleaf and pointed to something written in a careful, childish hand. It was a schedule, a daily plan for self-improvement. It was dated September 12, 1906, and it was filled with precise instructions: time for exercise, time for study, time for work, time for sports. Beneath it were a series of resolves: 'No wasting time. No smoking or chewing. Bath every day. Read something useful every day. Save money. Be better to parents.'

"This is what made him who he was," Mr. Gatz said, his voice trembling with emotion. "This is what made him Gatsby."

He read the items aloud, one by one, as if they were sacred words. He expected me to be deeply impressed, and I suppose I was, in a way. But I also felt a kind of sorrow, a sense that the man who had written those words had become something else entirely, something larger and more tragic than the boy who had once dreamed of a big future.
